This is about Autism Spectrum Disorder Guidance and Information txt. This is about Autism Spectrum Disorder Guidance and Information txt. Autism is a complex disorder and for more comprehensive \ninformation please use the references provided or contact Student Accessibility Services.  \n \nAutism Spectrum  Disorder Guidance and Information  \nAutism Spectrum Disorder is a developmental disorder of variable severity that is \ncharacterized by difficulty in social interaction and communication and by restricted or \nrepetitive patterns of thought and behavior.  https://www.lexico.com/en/definition/autism    \n \n\u2022 Verbal information takes more time to process  \n\u2022 Tone may unintentionally sound argumentative or arrogant  \n\u2022 Sarcasm or figures of s peech taken literally  \n\u2022 Poor ability to read non -verbal or body language  \n\u2022 Initiating, ending, and joining conversations may be difficult  \n\u2022 May misunderstand spatial boundaries  \n\u2022 May avoid eye contact  \n\u2022 May fixate on one topic  \n\u2022 May  misunderstand humor or share inappr opriate humor  \n\u2022 Communication skills break down if the individual is in distress  \n \n\u2022 May have ov ersensitivity to light, sound, smell, and /or touch  \n\u2022 May be u nder sensitive to pressure or pain     \n\u2022 Fine motor task difficultly is common  \n\u2022 Repetitive patterns of behavior may be seen  \n\u2022 May adhere rigidly to schedule or procedure   \n\u2022 Constant filtering of sensory information can be physically exhausting          \n\u2022 Can become sensory overloaded without exit or relief       \n\u2022 Intense negative situations may yield a fight or flight response  \n \n\u2022 May have difficulty organizing school assignments  \n\u2022 May struggle to initiate tasks  \n\u2022 May lack attention to detail  \n\u2022 May procrastinate on topics of little interest  \n\u2022 May hyper -focus on topics of interest  \n\u2022 May miss deadlines and due dates  due to poor time management\n", "lemma": "Autism be complex disorder more comprehensive information please use reference provide contact Student Accessibility Services. {"source": "Blind and Low Vision Guidance and Information1.txt", "text": "This is about Blind and Low Vision Guidance and Information txt. This is about Blind and Low Vision Guidance and Information txt. This is about Blind and Low Vision Guidance and Information txt. Blindness and Low Vision are complex disabilities and for \nmore comprehen sive information please use the references provided or contact Student Accessibility Services.  \nBlind and Low Vision Guidance and Information : Support Strategies  \n \n\u2022 Describe verbally what others can see  \n\u2022 Provide  verbal and electronically posted due dates, directions, and \nprocedures  \n\u2022 Face to face or Teams meetings may be preferable to email  \n\u2022 Check in frequently with the student to see  how they are accessing \ncourse information and be responsive  \n \n\u2022 Provide a description of the classroom layout and keep it consistent   \n\u2022 Cooperative groups should also be  guided to describe any meeting \nspace layout  \n\u2022 Allow space to navigate with cane or servic e dog or both   \n\u2022 Work ahead of time to process any needed Braille or Tactile Graphics \nneeded for the lesson  \n \n\u2022 Allow audio recording and software that audio records to support \nnotes as well as posted notes or peer notes  \n\u2022 Support  student  use of speech to text m echanisms or a scribe to \nproduce written work  \n\u2022 Be open to software and magnification devices that support \nstudents\u2019 access to the curriculum  \n\u2022 Follow online accessibility protocols for typed materials or Power \nPoint materials (see WebAIM link below)  \nResources and References:  \nAmerican Council of the Blind https://www.acb.org   \nNational Federation of the Blind https://www.nfb.org/    \nPortland State University (2016) Working with Blind Students at PSU 2016 -2017    \nhttps://docs.google.com/document/d/1fJvrHjx5iB1YmeiPin1o3LSe96FcmVkanf9L_p3VpVg/edit?usp=sharing   \nWeb AIM Web Accessibility in Mind (2020) Quick reference:  Web accessibility principles.  \nhttps://webaim.org/resources/quickref/#alt\n", "lemma": "Blindness Low Vision be complex disability more comprehen sive information please use reference provide contact Student Accessibility Services. Blind Low Vision Guidance Information Support Strategies \u2022 Describe verbally others see \u2022 Provide verbal electronically post due dates, directions, procedure \u2022 Face face Teams meeting be preferable email \u2022 Check frequently student see be access course information be responsive \u2022 Provide description classroom layout keep consistent \u2022 Cooperative group also be guide describe meeting space layout \u2022 Allow space navigate cane servic e dog \u2022 Work ahead time process needed Braille Tactile Graphics need lesson \u2022 Allow audio recording software audio record support note as well post note peer note \u2022 Support student use speech text m echanisms scribe produce write work \u2022 Be open software magnification device support students\u2019 access curriculum \u2022 Follow online accessibility protocol typed material Power Point material (see WebAIM link below) Resources References: American Council Blind https://www.acb.org National Federation Blind https://www.nfb.org/ Portland State University (2016) Working Blind Students PSU -2017 https://docs.google.com/document/d/1fJvrHjx5iB1YmeiPin1o3LSe96FcmVkanf9L_p3VpVg/edit?usp=sharing Web AIM Web Accessibility Mind (2020) Quick reference: Web accessibility principles. https://webaim.org/resources/quickref/#alt"}

This is about CAS Standards for Academic Advising txt. This statement may not be duplicated for other purposes without permission from CAS.  This standard and all other standards are available along with information on self-assessment procedures in the most recent edition of the CAS Professional Standards for Higher Education book. You are particularly encouraged to examine the learning and developmental outcomes (see www.cas.edu and in the standards book) in the design and assessment of your programs.  This standard has a Self-Assessment Guide (SAG) available for purchase from www.cas.edu for use in program evaluation.  CAS MISSION STATEMENT CAS, a consortium of professional associations in higher education, promotes the use of its professional standards for the development, assessment, and improvement of quality student learning, programs, and services  CAS STANDARDS AND GUIDELINES Each CAS standard contains 12 common criteria categories (referred to as \u201cgeneral standards\u201d) that have relevance for each and every functional area, no matter what its primary focus. In addition to the general standards, all functional area standards are comprised of both specialty standards and guidelines. Guidelines are designed to provide suggestions and illustrations that can assist in establishing programs and services that more fully address the needs of students than those mandated by a standard. CAS guidelines appear in regular font and use the auxiliary verbs \u201cshould\u201d and \u201cmay.\u201d  OVER THIRTY YEARS OF PROFESSIONAL SERVICES The Council for the Advancement of Standards in Higher Education (CAS) has been the pre-eminent force for promoting standards in student affairs, student services, and student development programs since its inception in 1979. For the ultimate purpose of fostering and enhancing student learning, development, and achievement and in general to promote good citizenship, CAS continues to create and deliver a dynamic and credible professional standards and guidelines and Self-Assessment Guides that are designed to lead to a host of quality-controlled programs and services. {"source": "CAS Standards for Academic Advising0.txt", "text": "This is about CAS Standards for Academic Advising txt. This is about CAS Standards for Academic Advising txt. This is about CAS Standards for Academic Advising txt. These standards respond to real-time student needs, the requirements of sound pedagogy, and the effective management of 45 functional areas, consistent with institutional missions. Individuals and institutions from more than 40 CAS member organizations comprise a professional constituency of over 100,000 professionals.   DISCLAIMER The standards and guidelines published in \u201cCAS Professional Standards for Higher Education\u201d by the Council for the Advancement of Standards in Higher Education (CAS) and referred to in each of the \u201cCAS Self-Assessment Guides\u201d (SAGs) are developed through the voluntary efforts of leaders of professional associations in higher education. The purpose of the standards and guidelines is to identify criteria and principles by which institutions may choose to assess and enhance various areas of their academic, administrative, or student affairs programs and services. CAS specifically disclaims any liability or responsibility for any perceived or actual shortcomings inherent in the text or application of the standards. This is about CAS Standards for Academic Advising txt. Part 3. ORGANIZATION AND LEADERSHIP  \n   \nTo achieve program and student learning and development outcomes, Academic Advising Programs \n(AAP) must be purposefully structured for effectiveness . AAP must have clearly stated and current  \n\u2022 goals and outcomes  \n\u2022 policies and procedures  \n\u2022 responsibilities and  performance expectations for personnel  \n\u2022 organizational charts demonstrating clear channels of authority  \n \nLeaders must model ethical behavior and institutional citizenship.  \n ", "lemma": "Part ORGANIZATION AND LEADERSHIP achieve program student learning development outcomes, Academic Advising Programs (AAP) be purposefully structure effectiveness AAP have clearly state current \u2022 goal outcome \u2022 policy procedure \u2022 responsibility performance expectation personnel \u2022 organizational chart demonstrate clear channel authority Leaders model ethical behavior institutional citizenship."}

Leaders with organizational authority for AAP  must provide strategic planning, manag ement and \nsupervision,  and program advancement.  \n Strategic Planning  \n\u2022 articulate a vision and mission that drive short-  and long -term planning  \n\u2022 set goals and objectives based on the needs of the populations served, intended student learning and development outcomes, and program outcomes  \n\u2022 facilitate continuous development, implementation, and assessment of program effectiveness and goal attainment congruent with institutional mission and strategic plans  \n\u2022 promote environments that provide opportunities for stude nt learning, development, and \nengagement  \n\u2022 develop, adapt, and improve programs and services in response to the changing needs of \npopulations served and evolving institutional priorities  \n\u2022 include diverse perspectives to inform decision making  \n \nManagement and Supervision  \n\u2022 plan, allocate, and monitor the use of fiscal, physical, human, intellectual, and technological resources  \n\u2022 manage human resource processes including recruitment, selection, professional development, supervision, performance planning, succession planning, evaluation, recognition, and reward  \n\u2022 influence others to contribute to the effectiveness and success of the unit  \n\u2022 empower professional, support, and student personnel to become effective leaders  \n\u2022 encourage and support collaboration with colleagues and departments across the institution  \n\u2022 encourage and support scholarly contributions to the profession\n", "lemma": "Leaders organizational authority AAP provide strategic planning, manag ement supervision, program advancement. {"source": "CAS Standards for Academic Advising11.txt", "text": "This is about CAS Standards for Academic Advising txt. This is about CAS Standards for Academic Advising txt. This is about CAS Standards for Academic Advising txt. Part 4. HUMAN RESOURCES  \n Academic Advising Programs (AAP) must be staffed adequately  by individuals qualified to accomplish \nmission and goals.  \n AAP must have access to technical and support personnel adequate to accomplish their mission.  \n \nSupport personnel and technical staff may maintain student records, organize resource materials, rece ive \nstudents, make appointments, handle correspondence, and meet other operational needs, as well as assist with research, data collection, systems development, and special projects.  \n \nWithin institutional guidelines, AAP must  \n\u2022 establish procedures for  perso nnel  recruitment and selection, training, performance planning, and \nevaluation  \n\u2022 set expectations for supervision and performance\n", "lemma": "Part HUMAN RESOURCES Academic Advising Programs (AAP) be staff adequately individual qualify accomplish mission goals. AAP have access technical support personnel adequate accomplish mission. Support personnel technical staff maintain student records, organize resource materials, rece ive students, make appointments, handle correspondence, meet other operational needs, as well assist research, data collection, system development, special projects. Within institutional guidelines, AAP \u2022 establish procedure perso nnel recruitment selection, training, performance planning, evaluation \u2022 set expectation supervision performance"}

Results of individual personnel evaluations must be used to recognize personnel performance, address performance issues, implement individual and/or collective personnel development and training programs, and inform the assessment of programs and services.   AAP personnel, when hired and throughout their employment, must receive appropriate and thorough training.  \n AAP personnel , including student employees and volunteers, must have access to resources or receive \nspecific training on  \n\u2022 institutional policies pertaining to functions or activities they support  \n\u2022 privacy and confidentiality policies  \n\u2022 laws regarding access to student records  \n\u2022 policies and procedures for dealing with s ensitive institutional information  \n\u2022 policies and procedures related to technology  used to store or access student records and \ninstitutional data  \n\u2022 how and when to refer those in need of additional assistance to qualified personnel and have access to a supervi sor for assistance in making these judgments  \n\u2022 systems and technologies necessary to perform their assigned responsibilities  \n\u2022 ethical and legal uses of technology  \n \nAAP personnel must engage in continuing professional development activities to keep abreast of  the \nresearch, theories, legislation, policies, and developments that affect their programs and services.  \n \nContinuing and regular professional development should address  \n\u2022 theories of student development, student learning, career development, and other relev ant theories  \n\u2022 academic advising approaches and best practices  \n\u2022 research, assessment, and evaluation processes \n\u2022 widely adopted purposes of academic advising and its relevance to student success at the institution\n", "lemma": "Results individual personnel evaluation be use recognize personnel performance, address performance issues, implement individual and/or collective personnel development training programs, inform assessment program services. AAP personnel must be knowledgeable of and trained in safety and emergency procedures for securing \nand vacating facilities.  \n \nPROFESSIONAL PERSONNEL  \n AAP professional personnel either must hold an earned graduate or profes sional degree in a field relevant \nto their position or must possess an appropriate combination of educational credentials and related work experience.   \n \nAcademic advising personnel may be full -time or part -time professionals for whom advising is a primary or \nsecondary function; they also may be faculty members whose responsibilities include advising. \nParaprofessionals (e.g., graduate students, interns, or assistants) and peer advisors may assist advisors.   \n \n", "lemma": "AAP personnel be knowledgeable train safety emergency procedure secure vacate facilities. {"source": "CAS Standards for Academic Advising14.txt", "text": "This is about CAS Standards for Academic Advising txt. This is about CAS Standards for Academic Advising txt. This is about CAS Standards for Academic Advising txt. Part 5. ETHICS  \n Academic Advising Programs (AAP) must  \n\u2022 review applicable professional ethical standards and must adopt or develop and implement \nappropriate statements of ethical practice  \n\u2022 publish and adhere to statements of ethical practice and ensure their periodic review  \n\u2022 orient new personnel to relevant ethical standards and statements of ethical practice and related \ninstitutional policies  \n \nAdvisors must uphold policies,  procedures, and priorities of their departments and institutions.  \n Statements of ethical standards must  \n\u2022 specify that programs and services personnel respect privacy and maintain confidentiality in \ncommunications and records as delineated by privacy laws  \n\u2022 specify limits on disclosure of information contained in students' records as well as requirements \nto disclose to appropriate authorities  \n\u2022 address conflicts of interest, or appearance thereof, by personnel in the performance of their work  \n\u2022 reflect the respo nsibility of personnel to be fair, objective, and impartial in their interactions with \nothers  \n\u2022 reference management of institutional funds  \n\u2022 reference appropriate behavior regarding research and assessment with human participants, confidentiality of research and assessment data, and students\u2019 rights and responsibilities   \n\u2022 include the expectation that personnel confront and hold accountable other personnel  who exhibit \nunethical behavior  \n\u2022 address issues surrounding scholarly integrity  \n  \nAAP personnel must  \n\u2022 employ e thical decision making in the performance of their duties  \n\u2022 inform users of programs and services of ethical obligations and limitations emanating from codes and laws or from licensure requirements  \n\u2022 recognize and avoid conflicts of interest that could adverse ly influence their judgment or \nobjectivity and, when unavoidable, recuse themselves from the situation\n", "lemma": "Part ETHICS Academic Advising Programs (AAP) \u2022 review applicable professional ethical standard adopt develop implement appropriate statement ethical practice \u2022 publish adhere statement ethical practice ensure periodic review \u2022 orient new personnel relevant ethical standard statement ethical practice related institutional policy Advisors uphold policies, procedures, priority department institutions. Statements ethical standard \u2022 specify program service personnel respect privacy maintain confidentiality communication record delineate privacy law \u2022 specify limit disclosure information contain students' record as well requirement disclose appropriate authority \u2022 address conflict interest, appearance thereof, personnel performance work \u2022 reflect respo nsibility personnel be fair, objective, impartial interaction others \u2022 reference management institutional fund \u2022 reference appropriate behavior regard research assessment human participants, confidentiality research assessment data, students\u2019 right responsibility \u2022 include expectation personnel confront hold accountable other personnel exhibit unethical behavior \u2022 address issue surround scholarly integrity AAP personnel \u2022 employ e thical decision making performance duty \u2022 inform user program service ethical obligation limitation emanate code law licensure requirement \u2022 recognize avoid conflict interest adverse ly influence judgment objectivity and, unavoidable, recuse situation"}
{"source": "CAS Standards for Academic Advising15.txt", "text": "This is about CAS Standards for Academic Advising txt. This is about CAS Standards for Academic Advising txt. This is about CAS Standards for Academic Advising txt. \u2022 perform their duties within the  scope of their position, training, expertise, and competence \n\u2022 make referrals when issues presented exceed the scope of the position  \n \nAAP personnel must recognize their responsibility to ensure the privileged, private, or confidential nature \nof advisors' interactions with students is not sacrificed.    \n \nPart 6. LAW, POLICY, AND GOVERNANCE  \n \nAcademic Advising Programs (AAP)  must be in compliance with laws, regulations, and policies that relate \nto their respective responsibilities and that pose legal obligations, limitations, risks, and liabilities for the institution as a whole. Examples include constitutional, statutory, regulato ry, and case law; relevant law \nand orders emanating from codes and laws; and the institution's policies.   \n Advisors  must be  knowledgeable about and sensitive to laws, regulations, policies, and procedures, \nparticularly those governing harassment, use of te chnology, personal relationships with students, privacy \nof student information,  non -discrimination, and equal opportunity policies.  \n AAP must have access to legal advice needed for personnel to carry out their assigned responsibilities.   ", "lemma": "\u2022 perform duty scope position, training, expertise, competence \u2022 make referral issue present exceed scope position AAP personnel recognize responsibility ensure privileged, private, confidential nature advisors' interaction student be not sacrificed. Part LAW, POLICY, AND GOVERNANCE Academic Advising Programs (AAP) be compliance laws, regulations, policy relate respective responsibility pose legal obligations, limitations, risks, liability institution whole. Examples include constitutional, statutory, regulato ry, case law; relevant law order emanate code laws; institution's policies. Advisors be knowledgeable sensitive laws, regulations, policies, procedures, particularly govern harassment, use te chnology, personal relationship students, privacy student information, non -discrimination, equal opportunity policies. AAP have access legal advice need personnel carry out assigned responsibilities."}

The revision and creation of policies must be in formed by best \npractices, available evidence, and policy issues in higher education.  \n \nAAP must have procedures and guidelines consistent with institutional policy for responding to threats, emergencies, and crisis situations. Systems and procedures must be  in place to disseminate timely and \naccurate information to students, other members of the institutional community, and appropriate external \norganizations during emergency situations.  \n \nPersonnel must neither participate in nor condone any form of harassme nt or activity that demeans \npersons or creates an intimidating, hostile, or offensive environment.  \n ", "lemma": "AAP regularly review revision creation policy be form best practices, available evidence, policy issue high education. {"source": "CAS Standards for Academic Advising16.txt", "text": "This is about CAS Standards for Academic Advising txt. This is about CAS Standards for Academic Advising txt. This is about CAS Standards for Academic Advising txt. Part 7. DIVERSITY, EQUITY, AND ACCESS   \n \nWithin the context of each institution's mission and in accordance with institutional policies and \napplicable codes and laws, Academic Advising Programs (AAP) must create and maintain educational and \nwork environments that are welcoming, accessible, inclusive, equitable, and free from harassment .  \n AAP must not discriminate on the basis of disability; age; race; cultural identity; ethnicity; nationality; family educational history (e.g., first generation to attend college); political affiliation; religious affiliation; sex; sexual orientation; gender  identity and expression; marital, social, economic, or veteran status; or any \nother basis included in institutional policies and codes and laws.  \n AAP must  \n\u2022 advocate for  sensitivity to multicultural and social justice concerns by the institution and its \npersonnel  \n\u2022 ensure physical, program, and resource access for all constituents  \n\u2022 modify or remove policies, practices, systems,  technologies, facilities, and structures that create \nbarriers or produce inequities  \n\u2022 ensure that when facilities and structures cannot be modified, they do not impede access to programs, services and resources  \n\u2022 establish goals for diversity, equity, and access  \n\u2022 foster communication and practices that  enhance understanding of identity, culture, self -\nexpression, and heritage  \n\u2022 promote respect for commonalities and differences among people within their historical and \ncultural contexts  \n\u2022 address the characteristics and needs of  diverse  constituents when establishing and implementing \nculturally relevant and inclusive programs, services, policies, pr ocedures, and practices  \n\u2022 provide  personnel  with diversity, equity, and access training and hold personnel accountable for \napplying the training to their work  \n\u2022 respond to the needs of all constituents served when establishing hours of operation and developing  methods of delivering programs, services, and resources  \n\u2022 recognize the needs of distance and online learning students by directly providing or assisting them to gain access to comparable services and resources   \n \nPart 8. INTERNAL  AND EXTERNAL RELATIONS  \n Academic Advising Programs (AAP) must reach out to  individuals, groups, communities, and \norganizations internal and external to the institution to  \n\u2022 establish, maintain, and promote understanding and effective relations with those that have a significant interest in or potential effect on the students or other constituents served by the \nprograms and services\n", "lemma": "Part DIVERSITY, EQUITY, AND ACCESS context institution's mission accordance institutional policy applicable code laws, Academic Advising Programs (AAP) create maintain educational work environment be welcoming, accessible, inclusive, equitable, free harassment AAP not discriminate basis disability; age; race; cultural identity; ethnicity; family educational history (e.g., first generation attend college); political affiliation; religious affiliation; sex; sexual orientation; gender identity expression; marital, social, economic, veteran status; other basis include institutional policy code laws. AAP \u2022 advocate sensitivity multicultural social justice concern institution personnel \u2022 ensure physical, program, resource access constituent \u2022 modify remove policies, practices, systems, technologies, facilities, structure create barrier produce inequity \u2022 ensure facility structure cannot be modified, do not impede access programs, service resource \u2022 establish goal diversity, equity, access \u2022 foster communication practice enhance understanding identity, culture, expression, heritage \u2022 promote respect commonality difference people historical cultural context \u2022 characteristic need diverse constituent establish implement culturally relevant inclusive programs, services, policies, pr ocedures, practice \u2022 provide personnel diversity, equity, access training hold personnel accountable apply training work \u2022 respond need constituent serve establish hour operation develop method deliver programs, services, resource \u2022 recognize need distance online learning student directly provide assist gain access comparable service resource Part INTERNAL AND EXTERNAL RELATIONS Academic Advising Programs (AAP) reach out individuals, groups, communities, organization internal external institution \u2022 establish, maintain, promote understanding effective relation have significant interest potential effect student other constituent serve program service"}
{"source": "CAS Standards for Academic Advising17.txt", "text": "This is about CAS Standards for Academic Advising txt. This is about CAS Standards for Academic Advising txt. This is about CAS Standards for Academic Advising txt. \u2022 garner support and resources for programs and services as defined by the mission  \n\u2022 collaborate  in offering or improving programs and services to meet th e needs of students and \nother constituents and to achieve program and student outcomes  \n\u2022 engage diverse individuals, groups, communities, and organizations to enrich the educational \nenvironment and experiences of students and other constituents  \n\u2022 disseminate information about the programs and services  \n \nPromotional and descriptive information must be accurate and free of deception and misrepresentation.  \n AAP must have procedures and guidelines consistent with institutional policy for  \n\u2022 communicating with the medi a \n\u2022 distributing information through print, broadcast, and online sources  \n\u2022 contracting with external organizations for delivery of programs and services  \n\u2022 cultivating, soliciting, and managing gifts  \n\u2022 applying to and managing funds from grants  \n \nFor referral purpo ses, AAP should maintain strong working relationships with relevant external agencies and \ncampus offices.  AAP should then provide comprehensive referral information to all who advise.  \n \n", "lemma": "\u2022 garner support resource program service define mission \u2022 collaborate offer improve program service meet th e need student other constituent achieve program student outcome \u2022 engage diverse individuals, groups, communities, organization enrich educational environment experience student other constituent \u2022 disseminate information program service Promotional descriptive information be accurate free deception misrepresentation. AAP have procedure guideline consistent institutional policy \u2022 communicate medi \u2022 distributing information print, broadcast, online source \u2022 contract external organization delivery program service \u2022 cultivating, soliciting, manage gift \u2022 apply manage fund grant referral purpo ses, AAP maintain strong work relationship relevant external agency campus offices. AAP then provide comprehensive referral information advise."}
{"source": "CAS Standards for Academic Advising17.txt", "text": "This is about CAS Standards for Academic Advising txt. This is about CAS Standards for Academic Advising txt. This is about CAS Standards for Academic Advising txt. Part 9. FINANCIAL RESOURCES  \n \nAcademic Advising Programs (AAP) must have  funding to accomplish the mission and goals.   \n In establishing and prioritizing funding resources, AAP must conduct comprehensive analyses  to \ndetermine  \n\u2022 unmet needs of the unit  \n\u2022 relevant expenditures  \n\u2022 external and internal resources  \n\u2022 impact on students and the institution  \n \nAAP must use the budget as a planning tool to reflect commitment to the mission and goals of the \nprograms and services and of the institution.  \n \nAAP must administer funds in accordance with established institutional accounting procedures.  \n \n", "lemma": "Part FINANCIAL RESOURCES Academic Advising Programs (AAP) have funding accomplish mission goals. establish prioritize funding resources, AAP conduct comprehensive analysis determine \u2022 unmet need unit \u2022 relevant expenditures \u2022 external internal resource \u2022 impact student institution AAP use budget planning tool reflect commitment mission goal program service institution. AAP administer fund accordance establish institutional accounting procedures."}

FACILITIES AND EQUIPMENT  \n \nAcademic Advising  Programs\u2019 (AAP) facilities must be intentionally designed and located in suitable, \naccessible, and safe spaces that demonstrate universal design and support the program\u2019s mission and goals.  \n \nFacilities must be designed to engage various constituents and promote learning.  \n Personnel must have workspaces that are suitably located and accessible, well equipped, adequate in size, \nand designed to support their work and responsibilities.   \n AAP must provide  work space that is private and free from visual and auditory distractions.  \n The design of the facilities must guarantee the security and privacy of records and ensure the \nconfidentiality of sensitive information and conversations. Personnel must b e able to secure their work.  \n \n", "lemma": "Part FACILITIES AND EQUIPMENT Academic Advising Programs\u2019 (AAP) facility be intentionally design locate suitable, accessible, safe space demonstrate universal design support program\u2019s mission goals. AAP provide work space be private free visual auditory distractions. design facility guarantee security privacy record ensure confidentiality sensitive information conversations. Personnel b e able secure work."}

ASSESSMENT  \n \nAcademic Advising Programs (AAP) must develop assessment plans and proces ses. \n \nAssessment plans must articulate an ongoing cycle of assessment activities.  \n AAP must  \n\u2022 specify programmatic goals and intended outcomes  \n\u2022 identify student learning and development outcomes  \n\u2022 employ multiple measures and methods  \n\u2022 develop manageable processes for gathering, interpreting, and evaluating data  \n\u2022 document progress toward achievement of goals and outcomes   \n\u2022 interpret and use assessment results to demonstrate accountability  \n\u2022 report aggregated results to respondent groups and stakeholders  \n\u2022 use assessment results to inform planning and decision -making  \n\u2022 assess effectiveness of implemented changes  \n\u2022 provide evidence of improvement  of programs and services  \n AAP must employ ethical practices in the assessment process.\n", "lemma": "ASSESSMENT Academic Advising Programs (AAP) develop assessment plan proces ses. {"source": "CAS Standards for Academic Advising4.txt", "text": "This is about CAS Standards for Academic Advising txt. This is about CAS Standards for Academic Advising txt. This is about CAS Standards for Academic Advising txt. Academic advis ors meet these obligations through applying frameworks for \ngood practice, including building partnerships with pivotal campus offices such as orientation, first -year student \nprograms, and career services.  \n \nAs the NACADA Concept of Academic Advising (NACADA, 2006)  delineates, academic advising objectives differ \namong institutions based upon the particular mission, goals, curriculum, co -curriculum, and assessment methods \nestablished for the respective campus (White, 2000). However, a representative sample of learning outcomes for \nadvising indicates that students will  \n\u2022 craft a coherent educational plan based on assessment of abilities, aspirations, interests, and values;  \n\u2022 use complex information from various sources to set goals, reach decisions, and achieve those goals;  \n\u2022 assume responsibility for meeting academic program requirements;  \n\u2022 articulate the meaning of higher education and the intent of the institution\u2019s curriculum;  \n\u2022 cultivate the intellectual habits that lead to a lifetime of learning; and  \n\u2022 behave as ci tizens who engage in the wider world around them (NACADA, 2006, para. 10).  \n \nThe increasing public attention placed on college completion means increased visibility for academic advising. \nReports such as Guided Pathways to Success  (Complete College America, 2013) point to academic advising as vital to \ndegree completion.  As institutions seek to increase and diversify enrollments, academic advisors are vital to ensuring \nappropriate matriculation and transfer leading to degree complet ion for all students. The evolving manner by which \nstudents complete college degrees, including the blending of courses offered on a variety of campuses and online, \nplaces new challenges on academic advisors, who must possess the tools needed to meet the d emands of students in \nvirtual space and across multiple institutions (Compete College America, 2013).  \n \nA crucial component of the college experience, academic advising encourages students to cultivate meaning in their \nlives, make significant decisions abou t their futures, and access institutional resources. When practiced with \ncompetence and dedication, academic advising is integral to student success, persistence, retention, and completion. Therefore, academic advisors must develop the tools and skills nec essary to address the many issues that influence \nstudent success and do so with respect to the increasing diversity on college and university campuses. The standards and guidelines in the Academic Advising Program Standards provide a framework for developi ng strong academic \nadvising programs.  \n \nReferences, Readings, and Resources  \n \nComplete College America. ", "lemma": "Academic advis or meet obligation apply framework good practice, include build partnership pivotal campus office such orientation, first -year student programs, career services. This is about CAS Standards for Academic Advising txt. ACADEMIC ADVISING PROGRAMS  \nCAS  Standards and Guidelines  \n \nPart 1. MISSION  \n \nThe mission of Academic Advising Programs (AAP) is to assist students as they define, plan, and achieve their educational goals. The AAP must advocate for student success and persistence.   ", "lemma": "ACADEMIC ADVISING PROGRAMS CAS Standards Guidelines Part MISSION mission Academic Advising Programs (AAP) be assist student define, plan, achieve educational goals. AAP advocate student success persistence."}
{"source": "CAS Standards for Academic Advising7.txt", "text": "This is about CAS Standards for Academic Advising txt. This is about CAS Standards for Academic Advising txt. This is about CAS Standards for Academic Advising txt. AAP must develop, disseminate, implement, and regularly review their missions, which must be consistent with the mission of the institution and with applicable professional standards.  The mission must be \nappropriate for the institution's students  and other constituents. Mission statements must reference \nstudent learni ng and development.  \n \nThe specific model used for AAP should be consistent with the mission, structure, and resources of the \ninstitution.  \n \n", "lemma": "AAP develop, disseminate, implement, regularly review missions, be consistent mission institution applicable professional standards. mission be appropriate institution's student other constituents. {"source": "CAS Standards for Academic Advising7.txt", "text": "This is about CAS Standards for Academic Advising txt. This is about CAS Standards for Academic Advising txt. This is about CAS Standards for Academic Advising txt. Part 2. PROGRAM   \n \nTo achieve their mission, Academic Advising Programs (AAP) must contribute to  \n\u2022 students' formal educa tion, which includes both the curriculum and the co -curriculum  \n\u2022 student progression and timely completion of educational goals  \n\u2022 preparation of students for their careers, citizenship, and lives  \n\u2022 student learning  and development  \n \nTo contribute to student learning and development, AAP must  \n\u2022 identify relevant and desirable student learning and development  outcomes  \n\u2022 articulate how the student learning and development outcomes align with the six CAS student learning and development domains and related dimensions  \n\u2022 asse ss relevant and desirable student learning and development  \n\u2022 provide evidence of impact on outcomes  \n\u2022 articulate contributions to or support of student learning and development in the domains not specifically assessed  \n\u2022 use evidence gathered to create strategies for improvement of programs and services  \n \nSTUDENT LEARNING AND DEVELOPMENT DOMAINS AND DIMENSIONS  \n \nDomain: knowledge acquisition, integration, construction, and application  \n \n\u2022 Dimensions: understanding knowledge from a range of disciplines; connecting knowledge to other knowledge, ideas, and experiences; constructing knowledge; and relating knowledge to daily life \n \nDomain: cognitive complexity\n", "lemma": "Part PROGRAM achieve mission, Academic Advising Programs (AAP) contribute \u2022 students' formal educa tion, include curriculum co -curriculum \u2022 student progression timely completion educational goal \u2022 preparation student careers, citizenship, live \u2022 student learning development contribute student learning development, AAP \u2022 identify relevant desirable student learning development outcome \u2022 articulate student learning development outcome align CAS student learn development domain related dimension \u2022 asse s relevant desirable student learning development \u2022 provide evidence impact outcome \u2022 articulate contribution support student learning development domain not specifically assessed \u2022 use evidence gather create strategy improvement program service STUDENT LEARNING AND DEVELOPMENT DOMAINS AND DIMENSIONS Domain: knowledge acquisition, integration, construction, application \u2022 Dimensions: understand knowledge range disciplines; connect knowledge other knowledge, ideas, experiences; constructing knowledge; relate knowledge daily life Domain: cognitive complexity"}

This is about CAS Standards for Academic Advising txt. \u2022 Dimensions: critical thinking, reflective thinking, effective reasonin g, and creativity  \n \nDomain: intrapersonal development  \n \n\u2022 Dimensions: realistic self -appraisal, self -understanding, and self -respect; identity development; \ncommitment to ethics and integrity; and spiritual awareness  \n \nDomain: interpersonal competence  \n \n\u2022 Dimension s: meaningful relationships, interdependence, collaboration, and effective leadership  \n \nDomain: humanitarianism and civic engagement  \n \n\u2022 Dimensions: understanding and appreciation of cultural and human differences, social \nresponsibility, global perspective, and sense of civic responsibility  \n \nDomain: practical competence  \n \n\u2022 Dimensions: pursuing goals, communicating effectively, technical competence, managing \npersonal affairs, managing career development, demonstrating professionalism, maintaining \nhealth and wellness, and living a purposeful and satisfying life  \n \n[LD Outcomes: See The Council for the Advancement of Standards Learning and Development Outcomes  statement for \nexamples of outcomes related to these domains and dimensions.]  \n \nAAP should determine which of the CAS learning and development domains and dimensions are most relevant to the advising functions on their campus and develop appropriate outcomes.  \n \n", "lemma": "\u2022 Dimensions: critical thinking, reflective thinking, effective reasonin g, creativity Domain: intrapersonal development \u2022 Dimensions: realistic self -appraisal, self -understanding, -respect; AAP must be  \n\u2022 intentionally designed  \n\u2022 guided by theories and knowledge of learning and development  \n\u2022 integrated into the life of the institution  \n\u2022 reflective of developmental and demographic profiles of the student population  \n\u2022 responsive to needs of individuals, populations with distinct needs, and relevant constituencies  \n\u2022 delivered using multiple formats, st rategies, and contexts  \n\u2022 designed to provide universal access  \n \nAAP must collaborate with colleagues and departments across the institution to promote student learning \nand development, persistence, and success.  \n AAP must provide the same quality of academic advising and in the appropriate  accessible forums to \ndistance learners as it does to students on campus.  \n Advisors must engage students in the shared responsibility of academic advising.\n", "lemma": "AAP be \u2022 intentionally design \u2022 guide theory knowledge learn development \u2022 integrate life institution \u2022 reflective developmental demographic profile student population \u2022 responsive need individuals, population distinct needs, relevant constituency \u2022 deliver use multiple formats, st rategies, context \u2022 design provide universal access AAP collaborate colleague department institution promote student learning development, persistence, success. This is about CAS Standards for Academic Advising txt. Advisors must provide opportunities that help inform student choice s and decisions about academic work \nand about educational, career, and life goals.  \n \nAdvisors should inform students that the ultimate responsibility for making decisions about educational plans \nand life goals rests with the individual student.    \n \nAAP must  be guided by a set of written goals and objectives that are directly related to its stated mission.   \n \nAcademic advisors should offer advising sessions in a format that is private and safe. {"source": "CAS Standards for Academic Advising9.txt", "text": "This is about CAS Standards for Academic Advising txt. This is about CAS Standards for Academic Advising txt. This is about CAS Standards for Academic Advising txt. Sessions should be convenient and accessible to the student, emplo ying the use of electronic and multimedia formats and \ntraditional in -person or telephone interactions as appropriate. Advising information sessions may be carried \nout individually or in groups, depending on the needs of the student and always with the stud ent's consent.  \n \nPrograms and  materials  associated with the AAP must   \n\u2022 promote student learning, development, and personal growth to encourage self -sufficiency  \n\u2022 support students, on an ongoing basis, as they establish and evaluate their educational, career, and life goals  \n\u2022 assist students in identifying the realistic timeframe to complete their educational goals and support their efforts  \n\u2022 provide  current and accurate advising information  \n\u2022 raise awareness  of institutional and community resources and services for students  \n\u2022 provide advisors with  training and development for making effective referrals to both on - and off-\ncampus services and agencies  \n\u2022 make advising available to students throughout their time at the institution  \n\u2022 proactively identify academically at -risk students and connect those students  with appropriate \nresources to facilitate student success  \n\u2022 employ appropriate and accessible technology to support the delivery of advising information  \n\u2022 clarify institutional policies and procedures for students  \n\u2022 monitor  academic progress and direct students to appropriate resources and programs  \n\u2022 advocate for appropriate resources to facilitate student success  \n\u2022 support learning and professional development for those involved in delivery of academic advising  \n\u2022 collect and d istribute relevant data regarding student needs, preferences, and performance for use \nin institutional decisions and policy  \n AAP must provide adequate resources to ensure that academic advising caseloads are consistent with the institutional mission and stated goals.    \n \nWhen institutional policy or process interferes with students' learning and development, the AAP must \nadvocate  for change using appropriate institutional means.  \n \n", "lemma": "Sessions be convenient accessible student, emplo ying use electronic multimedia format traditional -person telephone interaction appropriate. Advising information session be carry out individually groups, depend need student always stud ent's consent. Programs material associate AAP \u2022 promote student learning, development, personal growth encourage self -sufficiency \u2022 support students, ongoing basis, establish evaluate educational, career, life goal \u2022 assist student identify realistic timeframe complete educational goal support effort provide current accurate advise information \u2022 raise awareness institutional community resource service student \u2022 provide advisor training development make effective referral off- campus service agency \u2022 make advise available student time institution \u2022 proactively identify academically -risk student connect student appropriate resource facilitate student success \u2022 employ appropriate accessible technology support delivery advise information \u2022 clarify institutional policy procedure student \u2022 monitor academic progress direct student appropriate resource program \u2022 advocate appropriate resource facilitate student success \u2022 support learning professional development involve delivery academic advise \u2022 collect d istribute relevant data regard student needs, preferences, performance use institutional decision policy AAP provide adequate resource ensure academic advise caseloads be consistent institutional mission state goals. institutional policy process interferes students' learning development, AAP advocate change use appropriate institutional means."}

Dear academic advisors,  \n \nI\u2019m writing to alert you to revisions to the HSSA writing curriculum that Curriculum Committee passed \nthis month. These changes will be reflected in next year\u2019s catalog and degree requirements for our \nincoming freshmen \u2014but will also affect registration for  the small number of returning students who \nhave not yet earned credit for RH131 Rhetoric and Composition.  \n \nThe short version:  \nRH131  Rhetoric and Composition is replaced by  HUM H190  First -Year Writing Seminar  \nRH330  Technical and Professional Communication is renumbered as  ENGL H290  Technical and \nProfessional Communication  \n \nThe details:  \nIn addition to updating course numbers to fit the rest of the HSSA courses, this curriculum change \nrevises our approach to first -year writing. First -Year Writing Seminars ado pt a specific thematic focus in \na foundational course for our students\u2019 liberal education experience, including key learning outcomes \nfor critical thinking and communication. ", "lemma": "Dear academic advisors, I\u2019m writing alert revisions HSSA writing curriculum Curriculum Committee pass month. change be reflect next year\u2019s catalog degree requirement incoming freshman \u2014but also affect registration small number return student have not yet earn credit RH131 Rhetoric Composition. short version: RH131 Rhetoric Composition be replace HUM H190 First -Year Writing Seminar RH330 Technical Professional Communication be renumbered ENGL H290 Technical Professional Communication details: addition update course number fit rest HSSA courses, curriculum change revise approach first -year writing. First -Year Writing Seminars ado pt specific thematic focus foundational course students\u2019 liberal education experience, include key learning outcome critical thinking communication."}

Concept of Academic Advising   \nReprinted with permission from NACADA: The Global Community for Academi c \nAdvising  www.nacada.ksu.edu.   \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \nPREAMBLE   \nAcademic advising is integral to fulfilling the teaching and learning mission of higher education. \nThrough academic advising, students learn to become members of their higher  education \ncommunity, to think critically about their roles and responsibilities as students, and to prepare \nto be educated citizens of a democratic society and a global community. Academic advising \nengages students beyond their own world views, while ackn owledging their individual \ncharacteristics, values, and motivations as they enter, move through, and exit the institution. \nRegardless of the diversity of our institutions, our students, our advisors, and our organizational \nstructures, academic advising has  three components: curriculum (what advising deals with), \npedagogy (how advising does what it does), and student learning outcomes (the result of \nacademic advising).  \nTHE CURRICULUM OF ACADEMIC ADVISING   \nAcademic advising draws primarily from theories in t he social sciences, humanities, and \neducation. The curriculum of academic advising ranges from the ideals of higher education to \nthe pragmatics of enrollment. This curriculum includes, but is not limited to, the institution\u2019s \nmission, culture and expectati ons; the meaning, value, and interrelationship of the institution\u2019s \ncurriculum and co -curriculum; modes of thinking, learning, and decision -making; the selection \nof academic programs and courses; the development of life and career goals; \ncampus/community r esources, policies, and procedures; and the transferability of skills and \nknowledge.\n", "lemma": "curriculum academic advise range ideal high education pragmatic enrollment. curriculum includes, be not limited institution\u2019s mission, culture expectati ons; meaning, value, interrelationship institution\u2019s curriculum co -curriculum; mode thinking, learning, decision -making; selection academic program courses; development life career goals; campus/community r esources, policies, procedures; transferability skill knowledge."}
{"source": "Concept of Advising1.txt", "text": "This is about Concept of Advising txt. This is about Concept of Advising txt. This is about Concept of Advising txt. THE PEDAGOGY OF ACADEMIC ADVISING   \nAcademic advising, as a teaching and learning process, requires a pedagogy that incorporates \nthe preparation, facilitation, documentati on, and assessment of advising interactions. Although \nthe specific methods, strategies, and techniques may vary, the relationship between advisors \nand students is fundamental and is characterized by mutual respect, trust, and ethical behavior.  \nSTUDENT LEARNING OUTCOMES OF ACADEMIC ADVISING   \nThe student learning outcomes of academic advising are guided by an institution\u2019s mission, \ngoals, curriculum and co -curriculum. These outcomes, defined in an advising curriculum, \narticulate what students will  demonstrate, know, value, and do as a result of participating in \nacademic advising. Each institution must develop its own set of student learning outcomes and \nthe methods to assess them. ", "lemma": "PEDAGOGY OF ACADEMIC ADVISING Academic advising, teaching learn process, require pedagogy incorporate preparation, facilitation, documentati on, assessment advise interactions. specific methods, strategies, technique vary, relationship advisor student be fundamental be characterize mutual respect, trust, ethical behavior. STUDENT LEARNING OUTCOMES OF ACADEMIC ADVISING student learn outcome academic advising be guide institution\u2019s mission, goals, curriculum co -curriculum. outcomes, define advise curriculum, articulate student demonstrate, know, value, do result participate academic advising. institution develop own set student learn outcome method assess them."}

Students will:  \n\uf0a7 craft a co herent educational plan based on assessment of abilities, aspirations, interests, and \nvalues  \n\uf0a7 use complex information from various sources to set goals, reach decisions, and achieve \nthose goals  \n\uf0a7 assume responsibility for meeting academic program requirements  \n\uf0a7 articulate the meaning of higher education and the intent of the institution\u2019s curriculum  \n\uf0a7 cultivate the intellectual habits that lead to a lifetime of learning  \n\uf0a7 behave as citizens who engage in the wider world around them  \n \nSUMMARY   \nAcademic advising, based in the teaching and learning mission of higher education, is a series of \nintentional interactions with a curriculum, a pedagogy, and a set of student learning outcomes. \nAcademic advising synthesizes and contextualizes students\u2019 educational experiences with in the \nframeworks of their aspirations, abilities and lives to extend learning beyond campus \nboundaries and timeframes.\n", "lemma": "Students will: \uf0a7 craft co herent educational plan base assessment abilities, aspirations, interests, value \uf0a7 use complex information various source set goals, reach decisions, achieve goal \uf0a7 assume responsibility meet academic program requirement \uf0a7 articulate meaning high education intent institution\u2019s curriculum \uf0a7 cultivate intellectual habit lead lifetime learn \uf0a7 behave citizen engage wider world SUMMARY Academic advising, base teaching learn mission high education, be series intentional interaction curriculum, pedagogy, set student learn outcomes. {"source": "Core Competencies0.txt", "text": "This is about Core Competencies txt. This is about Core Competencies txt. This is about Core Competencies txt. \u2022 Learning Professionals, Trainers, and Researchers  to support curriculum development, establish learning \npriorities, and advance scholarship in the field.\nUnderpinning the core competencies for academic advising and serving as the foundational elements for effective advisor training programs and advising practice are three content components \u2013 the conceptual, informational, and relational.  An understanding of these content areas provides advisors the knowledge and skills to be effective guides for their students. \n \n\u2022 The Conceptual component provides the context for \nthe delivery of academic advising.  It covers the ideas and theories that advisors must understand to effectively advise their students.\n\u2022 The Informational component provides the substance \nof academic advising.  It covers the knowledge advisors must gain to be able to guide the students at their institution.\n\u2022 The Relational component provides the skills that \nenable academic advisors to convey the concepts and information from the other two components to their advisees.\nTo achieve excellence in their work, regardless of the specifics of their individual campus\u2019 advising mission, all academic advisors must understand all three components and be able to synthesize and apply them as needed in academic advising interactions.\n", "lemma": "\u2022 Learning Professionals, Trainers, Researchers support curriculum development, establish learning priorities, advance scholarship field. Underpinning core competency academic advising serving foundational element effective advisor training program advise practice be content component \u2013 conceptual, informational, relational. understanding content area provide advisor knowledge skill be effective guide students. Conceptual component provide context delivery academic advising. cover idea theory advisor understand effectively advise students. Informational component provide substance academic advising. cover knowledge advisor gain be able guide student institution. Relational component provide skill enable academic advisor convey concept information other component advisees. achieve excellence work, regardless specific individual campus\u2019 advise academic advisor understand component be able synthesize apply need academic advising interactions."}

Advisors are committed to \nstudents, colleagues, institutions, and \nthe profession through assessment, \nscholarly inquiry, life-long \nlearning, and professional \ndevelopment.\nThe NACADA Statement of \nCore Values reflects the \nmany cultural and \neducational contexts in which \nacademic advising is practiced globally. A \ndiverse, globally represented task force in \nconjunction with the input of NACADA members contributed to the creation of the \nstatement. {"source": "Deaf%20and%20Hard%20of%20Hearing%20Guidance%20and%20Informat0.txt", "text": "This is about Deaf and Hard of Hearing Guidance and Informat txt. This is about Deaf and Hard of Hearing Guidance and Informat txt. This is about Deaf and Hard of Hearing Guidance and Informat txt. Deaf and Hard of Hearing are  complex di sabilities  and for \nmore comprehensive information please use the references provided or contact Student Accessibility Services.  \n \nDeaf and Hard of Hearing Guidance and Information  \nThe definition of deafness  from the  IDEA is a hearing impairment that is so severe that the child is impaired in \nprocessing linguistic information through hearing, with or without amplification.   The definition of hearing \nimpairment is an impairment in hearing, whether permanent or fluctuating, that adversely affects a child\u2019s \neducational performance but that is not included under the definition of \ndeafness .  https://sites.ed.gov/idea/regs/b/a/300.8/c/5   \n \n\u2022 Ways of communicating may vary for individuals that are deaf \nor hard of hearing (speech only, sign language, fingerspelling, \nlip reading, writing/reading , with an interpreter,  captioning, or \nany combination)   \n\u2022 Interpreters generally can only capture 50 -60% of oral lectures \nso multiply means of relaying content is needed  \n  \n \n\u2022 Deaf or hard of hearing students generally may sit near the \nfront of the classroom  \n\u2022 Watching in tently and trying to capture course information is \nexhausting   \n\u2022 Socially it can be isolating to be deaf or hard of hearing  \n \n \n \n \n\u2022 The deaf or hard of hearing student is trying to capture all the \ncourse components that others can hear\n", "lemma": "Deaf Hard Hearing be complex di sabilities more comprehensive information please use reference provide contact Student Accessibility Services. Deaf Hard Hearing Guidance Information definition deafness IDEA be hearing impairment be so severe child be impair process linguistic information hearing, definition hear impairment be impairment hearing, permanent fluctuating, adversely affect child\u2019s educational performance be not include definition deafness https://sites.ed.gov/idea/regs/b/a/300.8/c/5 \u2022 Ways communicating vary individual be deaf hard hear (speech only, sign language, fingerspelling, lip reading, writing/reading interpreter, captioning, combination) \u2022 Interpreters generally only capture -60% oral lecture so multiply mean relay content be need \u2022 Deaf hard hear student generally sit front classroom \u2022 Watching tently try capture course information be exhaust \u2022 Socially be isolate be deaf hard hear deaf hard hear student be try capture course component others hear"}
{"source": "Deaf%20and%20Hard%20of%20Hearing%20Guidance%20and%20Informat1.txt", "text": "This is about Deaf and Hard of Hearing Guidance and Informat txt. This is about Deaf and Hard of Hearing Guidance and Informat txt. This is about Deaf and Hard of Hearing Guidance and Informat txt. This guidance and infor mation page is a quick reference tool.  Deaf and Hard of Hearing are  complex di sabilities  and for \nmore comprehensive information please use the references provided or contact Student Accessibility Services.  \n \nDeaf and Hard of Hearing  Guidance and Information :  Support Strategies  \n \n\u2022 Be accepting of how the student communicates  \n\u2022 Support multiple means of capturing the lecture /lab \n\u2022 Be sure to have the  student 's attention before speaking  \n\u2022 Speak or rephrase what you have said facing the student  \n\u2022 Speak slowly and clearly  \n\u2022 Speak directly to the student and not the interpreter  \n\u2022 Student have an amplifying device to be used by the professor or at \nthe front of the classroom  \n \n\u2022 May need to sit near th e front to see the professor speak and read \nexpressions  \n\u2022 May need to sit so they can see an interpreter that may be located \nnear the professor  \n\u2022 May need alerting if there is an audible fire drill or alarm  \n\u2022 Student and interpreter m ay need additional breaks  \n\u2022 May need support with cooperative pairings  \n \n\u2022 Printed materials, procedure s, due dates and timelines  are \nsupportive  \n\u2022 Providing Power Point slides or notes prior to class to the student \nand/or the interpreter is supportive  and proactive  \n\u2022 Assigned, online, or in -class videos should be captioned (work with \nLearning and Technology  ahead of time to support captioning)   \n\u2022 Positive feedback and frequent check -ins are helpful  \nResources and References:  \nNational Deaf Center (NDC) https://www.nationaldeafcenter.org/   \nNational Association of the Deaf (NAD)  https://www.nad.org/  \nUS Department of Justice. (2020) ADA requirements:  Effective communications  https://www.ada.gov/effective -comm.htm  \nWestern Region Outreach Center & Consortia at The National Center on Deafness (2020)  Guide to working with deaf and hard of \nhearing students . ", "lemma": "guidance infor mation page be quick reference tool. Deaf Hard Hearing be complex di sabilities more comprehensive information please use reference provide contact Student Accessibility Services. Deaf Hard Hearing Guidance Information Support Strategies \u2022 Be accept student communicate \u2022 Support multiple mean capture lecture /lab \u2022 Be sure have student attention speak \u2022 Speak rephrase have say face student \u2022 Speak slowly clearly \u2022 Speak directly student not interpreter \u2022 Student have amplifying device be use professor front classroom \u2022 May need sit th e front see professor speak read expression \u2022 May need sit see interpreter be locate professor \u2022 May need alert be audible fire drill alarm Student interpreter m ay need additional break \u2022 May need support cooperative pairing \u2022 Printed materials, procedure s, due date timeline be supportive \u2022 Providing Power Point slide note prior class student and/or interpreter be supportive proactive \u2022 Assigned, online, -class video be caption (work Learning Technology ahead time support captioning) \u2022 Positive feedback frequent check -ins be helpful Resources References: National Deaf Center (NDC) https://www.nationaldeafcenter.org/ National Association Deaf (NAD) https://www.nad.org/ US Department Justice. (2020) ADA requirements: Effective communication https://www.ada.gov/effective -comm.htm Western Region Outreach Center Consortia National Center Deafness (2020) Guide work deaf hard hear student"}

ESL Placements:\nAll incoming international students take an English skills assessment during \nthe summer to assess their language skills and determine their ESL course \nplacements.  \nThe test consists of: \na) a 20 -minute oral interview conducted via Skype; \nb) a proctored writing test administered via Moodle;\nc) a standardized listening/reading/grammar test\ndelivered through a proctored online platform.  \nMost ESL placements will be finalized by the end of the 3rd week of August.  \n", "lemma": "ESL Placements: All incoming international student take English skill assessment summer assess language skill determine ESL course placements. test consist of: a) -minute oral interview conduct Skype; b) proctored writing test administer Moodle; c) standardized listening/reading/grammar test deliver proctored online platform. Most ESL placement be finalize end week August."}

{"source": "Effortless Advising Tip Sheet1.txt", "text": "This is about Effortless Advising Tip Sheet txt. This is about Effortless Advising Tip Sheet txt. This is about Effortless Advising Tip Sheet txt. For          \nexample, document recurring email responses so that you can copy/paste in the future.  Bookmark any My \nRose -Hulman pages or any other websites you reference often in order to reduce the number of clicks.  \n \nTRUST :  Trust is essential in an advising relationship, and high -trust relationships require less overall effort.        \nConsider establishing clear roles (\u201cAs the advisor, I will do this; as the advisee, you should do that \u201d) and     \nexpectations (e.g., how to schedule a meeting; what to prepare ahead of time; consequences for not meeting \nexpectations).  This might also include sharing tips and highlighting resources available to help with tasks.  \n \nPREVENT : To reduce frustration, try to solve problems before they happen.  Consider using the scheduler \nactivity in your Moodle course to schedule appointments.  Not only will this reduce the number of back -and-\nforth emails, but the scheduler activity can send reminders to students.  You can set up a reminder of the   \nappointment (from the morning of, to several days out); you can even quickly send a reminder email to those \nwho have not yet scheduled their meeting.  \nYour turn! This is about FERPA Exceptions txt. 34 CFR \u00a7\u00a7 99.31(a)(3) and 99.35.  \nOther notes  \nRecord\nation: FERPA does not \nrequire educational agencies and institutions to reco rd \ndisclosures of appropriately \ndesignated directory \ninformation (\u00a7 99.32(d)(4)).  Recordation : FERPA \n(\u00a7 99.32(d)(2)) does not require \neducational agencies and \ninstitutions to record disclosures of PII from \neducation records to school officials under \u00a7 99.31(a)(1).  Recordation : FERPA requires \neducational agencies and \ninstitutions to record all \ndisclosures of PII from education records to \norganizations made under the \nstudies exception (\u00a7 99.32).   Recordation : FERPA requires educational agencies and \ninstitutions to record all disclosures of PII from education \nrecords made under the audit or evaluation exception \n(\u00a7 99.32).  \n\uf0d8State and local educational authorities (and other\nFERPA -permitted entities listed in \u00a7 99.31(a)(3))\nredisclosing PII on behalf of the educational agency\nor institution must record disclosures according to the\nrequirements in \u00a7 99.32(b)(2).\nSee\t\r \u00a0PTAC\t\r \u00a0website\t\r \u00a0for\t\r \u00a0Additional\t\r \u00a0Resources\t\r \u00a0and\t\r \u00a0Glossary:\t\r \u00a0 http://ptac.ed.gov \t\r \u00a0\nPTAC-Handout-2H, April 2014 \t\r \u00a0\nhttp://ptac.ed.gov\n", "lemma": "CFR \u00a7\u00a7 Other note Record ation: FERPA do not require educational agency institution reco rd disclosure appropriately designate directory information Recordation FERPA (\u00a7 do not require educational agency institution record disclosure PII education record school official \u00a7 Recordation FERPA require educational agency institution record disclosure PII education record organization make study exception Recordation FERPA require educational agency institution record disclosure PII education record make audit evaluation exception (\u00a7 \uf0d8State local educational authority (and other FERPA -permitted entity list \u00a7 redisclosing PII behalf educational agency institution record disclosure accord requirement \u00a7 See PTAC website Additional Resources Glossary: http://ptac.ed.gov PTAC-Handout-2H, April http://ptac.ed.gov"}

{"source": "Learning Disability Guidance and Information Sheet0.txt", "text": "This is about Learning Disability Guidance and Information Sheet txt. This is about Learning Disability Guidance and Information Sheet txt. This is about Learning Disability Guidance and Information Sheet txt. Learning Disabilities are complex and diverse  and for more \ncomprehensive information please use the references provided or conta ct Student Accessibility Services.  \n \nLearning Disability  Guidance and Information  \nThe Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA) defines a  Specific Learning \nDisability  (SLD) as \u201ca disorder in one or more of the basic psychological processes involved in \nunderstanding or in using language, spoken or written, that may manifest itself in the \nimperfect ability to listen, think, speak, read, write, spell, or to do mathematical \ncalcu lations.\u201d SLD is the most common category under IDEA. Categories of SLD include \ndyslexia, dysgraphia, dyscalculia, auditory processing disorde r, and nonverbal learning \ndisability.    https://www.understood.org/en/school -learning/special -services/special -\neducation -basics/conditions -covered -under -idea   \n \n\u2022 May prefer face to face communication with faculty and/or \ncollaborative gr oups  \n\u2022 May struggle to read handwriting and/or printed \nmaterial/email  \n\u2022 Verbal r esponse may be delayed due to auditory processing    \n \n\u2022 May have visual/spatial challenges  \n\u2022 May have difficulty with handwriting and note taking  \n\u2022 May have an auditory processing delay   \n\u2022 May have difficulty transferring writing from the board to \npaper  \n \n \n \n\u2022 May have difficulty organizing school assignments  \n\u2022 May take longer to complete written work  \n\u2022 May miss verbal directions due  an auditory processing delay  \n\u2022 In general, it takes a few days to set up in -class note takers and \nelectronic text versions at the beginning of a quarter\n", "lemma": "Learning Disabilities be complex diverse more comprehensive information please use reference provide conta ct Student Accessibility Services. Learning Disability Guidance Information Individuals Disabilities Education Act (IDEA) define Specific Learning Disability (SLD) \u201ca disorder more basic psychological process involve understand use language, spoken written, manifest imperfect ability listen, think, speak, read, write, spell, do mathematical calcu lations.\u201d SLD be most common category IDEA. Categories SLD include dyslexia, dysgraphia, dyscalculia, auditory processing disorde r, nonverbal learning disability. https://www.understood.org/en/school -learning/special -services/special education -basics/conditions -covered -under -idea \u2022 May prefer face face communication faculty and/or collaborative gr oups \u2022 May struggle read handwrite and/or print material/email \u2022 Verbal r esponse be delay due auditory processing \u2022 May have visual/spatial challenge \u2022 May have difficulty handwriting note take \u2022 May have auditory processing delay \u2022 May have difficulty transfer write board paper \u2022 May have difficulty organize school assignment \u2022 May take long complete write work \u2022 May miss verbal direction due auditory processing delay \u2022 general, take few day set up -class note taker electronic text version beginning quarter"}
{"source": "Learning Disability Guidance and Information Sheet1.txt", "text": "This is about Learning Disability Guidance and Information Sheet txt. This is about Learning Disability Guidance and Information Sheet txt. This is about Learning Disability Guidance and Information Sheet txt. Learning Disabilities are complex and diverse  and for more \ncomprehensive information please use the references provided or conta ct Student Accessibility Services.  \n \nLearning Disability Guidance and Information :  Support Strategies  \n \n\u2022 Provide verbal as well as  electronically printed  due dates  and \ndirections  \n\u2022 Provide pdf or word documents electronically with  non-serif font to \nsupport reading software   \n\u2022 Understand that meeting face to face or on Teams with faculty \nand/or collaborative groups  may be preferred to email  \n \n\u2022 Understand  that handwriting  and/or audio processing may be \nimpacted and supports such as audio recording to capture lecture \nnotes to play  back  or copies of notes  are supportive  \n\u2022 The ability to use a laptop keyboard to word process notes/longer \nwritten tests or assignments is supporti ve when students have \ndysgraphia  \n \n\u2022 Textbooks with an alternative electronic format to support reading \nsoftware (Accesstext, Bookshare, and larger publishing companies \nprovide this when the student has purchased a text)  \n\u2022 Speech to Text software to support writing  \n\u2022 Text to speech software to read electronic notes, textbooks  \n\u2022 Most written work simply takes more time for a student with SLD  \n\u2022 Be supportive of timeframe to set up accommodations  \n\u2022 Positive feedback and frequent check -ins are  helpful  \nResources a nd References:  \nNational Center for Learning Disabilities https://www.ncld.org/   \nCouncil for Learning Disabilities https://council -for-learning -disabilities.org/   \nCouncil for Learning Disabilities. (2016) College: A realistic option for students with learning disabilities.  ", "lemma": "Learning Disabilities be complex diverse more comprehensive information please use reference provide conta ct Student Accessibility Services.
