{"source": "Civil%20Engineering.txt", "text": "This is about Civil Engineering txt. This is about Civil Engineering txt. This is about Civil Engineering txt. The civil engineering program uses the term \"educational objective\" to describe the expected accomplishments of our students in three to five years following graduation. The term \"student learning outcome\" is used to describe knowledge and skills at the time of graduation.\n\nThe civil engineering program is accredited by the Engineering Accreditation Commission of ABET, https://www.abet.org, under the commission\u2019s General Criteria and Program Criteria for Civil and Similarly Named Engineering Programs.\n\nEnvironmental Engineering\u00a0Minor\n\nThe Environmental Engineering\u00a0minor includes five (5) required courses and 8 elective credit hours. The required courses provide an introduction to the overall field of environmental engineering. The elective courses allow the student to tailor the minor to their interests.\n\nThe five (5) required courses are as follows:\n\nCE 460 Introduction to Environmental Engineering BIO 107 Introduction to Environmental Science CE 562/CHE 562 Advanced Wastewater Treatment CE 563/CHE 563 Advanced Water Treatment CE 564 Aqatic Environmental Chemistry\n\nAnd eight (8) credit hours from the following courses:\n\nCE 565 Solid and Hazardous Waste Regulation and Treatment CE 567 Applied Hydrologic Modeling CE 568 Surface Water Quality Modeling CE 570 Modeling Open Channel Hydraulics CE 571 Environmental River Mechanics CE 573 Groundwater Analysis CE 590 Special Problems CHE 462 Membrane Separations CHE 465 Energy and the Environment CHE 470 Safety, Health, and Loss Prevention CHEM 535 {"source": "Computer%20Engineering.txt", "text": "This is about Computer Engineering txt. This is about Computer Engineering txt. This is about Computer Engineering txt. Computer Engineering\n\nComputer Engineers (CPE) are electrical engineers that have additional training in the areas of software design and hardware-software integration. Common CPE tasks include writing embedded software for real-time microcontrollers, designing VLSI chips, working with analog sensors, designing mixed signal circuit boards, and designing operating systems. Computer engineers are also well-suited for research in the field of robotics, which relies on using computers together with other electrical systems. Below is a recommended plan of study for CPE.\n\nCPE program educational objectives\n\nComputer Engineering graduates shall:\n\nPractice excellence in their profession using a systems approach encompassing technological, economic, ethical, environmental, social, and human issues within a changing global environment;\n\nFunction independently and in leadership positions within multidisciplinary teams;\n\nContinue life-long learning by acquiring new knowledge, mastering emerging technologies, and using\u00a0 appropriate tools and methods;\n\nAdapt and independently extend their learning to excel in fields about which they are passionate;\n\nStrengthen teams and communities through collaboration, effective communication, public service, and leadership.\n\nCPE Student Learning Outcomes\n\nAt the time of graduation, students will have demonstrated:\n\nan ability to identify, formulate, and solve complex engineering problems by applying principles of engineering, science, and mathematics\n\nan ability to apply engineering design to produce solutions that meet specified needs with consideration of public health, safety, and welfare, as well as global, cultural, social, environmental, and economic factors\n\nan ability to communicate effectively with a range of audiences\n\nan ability to recognize ethical and professional responsibilities in engineering situations and make informed judgments, which must consider the impact of engineering solutions in global, economic, environmental, and societal contexts\n\nan ability to function effectively on a team whose members together provide leadership, create a collaborative and inclusive environment, establish goals, plan tasks, and meet objectives\n\nan ability to develop and conduct appropriate experimentation, analyze and interpret data, and use engineering judgment to draw conclusions\n\nan ability to acquire and apply new knowledge as needed, using appropriate learning strategies.\n\nThe computer engineering program is accredited by the Engineering Accreditation Commission of ABET, https://www.abet.org, under the commission\u2019s General Criteria and Program Criteria for Electrical, Computer, Communications, Telecommunication(s), and Similarly Named Engineering Programs.\n\n", "lemma": "Computer Engineering Computer Engineers (CPE) be electrical engineer have additional training area software design hardware-software integration. Common CPE task include write embed software real-time microcontrollers, design VLSI chips, work analog sensors, design mixed signal circuit boards, design operate systems. Computer engineer be also well-suited research field robotics, rely use computer together other electrical systems. Below be recommended plan study CPE. CPE program educational objective Computer Engineering graduate shall: Practice excellence profession use system approach encompass technological, economic, ethical, environmental, social, human issue change global environment; Function independently leadership position multidisciplinary teams; Continue life-long learning acquire new knowledge, master emerge technologies, use appropriate tool methods; Adapt independently extend learning excel field be passionate; Strengthen team community collaboration, effective communication, public service, leadership. {"source": "Computer%20Science.txt", "text": "This is about Computer Science txt. This is about Computer Science txt. This is about Computer Science txt. The department\u2019s courses emphasize fundamental concepts and techniques that will last longer than present technology.\n\nComputer science majors complete a core of basic computer science courses that includes the study of algorithms, data structures, database concepts, computer architecture, programming languages, operating systems, and software engineering. Majors also complete important courses in closely related fields, e.g., discrete mathematics, digital logic design, and probability and statistics. The major requires students to study all aspects of the science of computing, including hardware, software, and theory.\n\nCourses in database systems, compilers, computer graphics, fractals and chaotic dynamical systems, artificial intelligence, theory of computation, analysis of algorithms, computer networks, computer vision, web-based information systems, and cryptography are available as advanced electives. A three-term senior project provides valuable practical experience in the specification, design, implementation, and documentation of large software systems. ", "lemma": "department\u2019s course emphasize fundamental concept technique last long present technology. The student chapter of the Association for Computing Machinery provides seminars and other technical activities throughout the year and sponsors the school\u2019s programming teams which compete in local, regional, and national contests. The national computer science honor society, Upsilon Pi Epsilon, has chartered its Indiana Alpha Chapter at Rose-Hulman.\n\nComputer Science Program Educational Objectives\n\nGraduates from the computer science program will be prepared for many types of careers in the field of computing and be prepared for graduate study in computer science and in closely related disciplines. In the early phases of their careers, we expect\n\nRose-Hulman computer science graduates to be:\n\nComputing professionals in a variety of organizations, including ones doing traditional software development, technological innovation, and cross-disciplinary work\n\nBusiness and technological leaders within existing organizations\n\nEntrepreneurial leaders\n\nRecognized by their peers and superiors for their communication, teamwork, and leadership skills\n\nActively involved in social and professional service locally, nationally, and globally\n\nGraduate students and researchers\n\nLeaders in government and law as government employees, policy makers, governmental advisors, and legal professionals\n\nComputer Science Student Outcomes\n\nGraduates of the program will have an ability to:\n\nAnalyze a complex computing problem and to apply principles of computing and other relevant disciplines to identify solutions.\n\nDesign, implement, and evaluate a computing-based solution to meet a given set of computing requirements in the context of the program\u2019s discipline.\n\n", "lemma": "student chapter Association Computing Machinery provide seminar other technical activity year sponsor school\u2019s program team compete local, regional, national contests. national computer science honor society, Upsilon Pi Epsilon, have charter Indiana Alpha Chapter Rose-Hulman. {"source": "Data-Science-SMO.txt", "text": "This is about Data Science SMO txt. This is about Data Science SMO txt. This is about Data Science SMO txt. Data Science (Second Major Only)\n\nRequirements\n\nData Science is open to all students as a second major; this means that the student will have some other discipline as their primary major.\u00a0 Students whose primary major is in Computer Science, Software Engineering or Mathematics will find the Data Science program the easiest since there is considerable overlap between those programs and the Data Science requirements\u00a0 Students from other disciplines are also encouraged to participate, but will have to take more courses.\u00a0 All students are encouraged to take the individual courses in the program, regardless of whether they wish to fulfill the second major requirements.\n\nData Science requires 72 course credit hours and a senior capstone experience; these include 36 hours of Fundamental data science topics, 20 hours in Advanced topics, and 16 hours in Electives.\u00a0 The 36 fundamental credit hours and no more than 8 of the elective credit hours may be used to satisfy any requirements for another major (primary or secondary) or minor; students with a second major in Data Science cannot earn a minor in Data Science as well.\u00a0 Thus, the 20 Advanced credit hours and at least 8 Elective credit hours can only be used to satisfy technical and free electives of another major program.\n\nFurthermore, Data Science majors are expected to complete a Senior Project or Senior Thesis in either their primary major or within either the Computer Science and Software Engineering Department or the Mathematics Department, and that this work includes a data science component.\n\nData Science Program Student Outcomes\n\n1.\u00a0\u00a0Provide leadership in both mathematical and computer science aspects of using data and solving related problems.\n\n", "lemma": "Data Science (Second Major Only) Requirements Data Science be open student second major; mean student have other discipline primary major. Students primary major be Computer Science, Software Engineering Mathematics find Data Science program easy be considerable overlap program Data Science requirement Students other discipline be also encourage participate, have take more courses. student be encourage take individual course program, regardless wish fulfill second major requirements. Data Science require course credit hour senior capstone experience; include hour Fundamental data science topics, hour Advanced topics, hour Electives. fundamental credit hour more elective credit hour be use satisfy requirement major (primary secondary) minor; student second major Data Science cannot earn minor Data Science well. Thus, Advanced credit hour least Elective credit hour only be use satisfy technical free elective major program. Furthermore, Data Science major be expect complete Senior Project Senior Thesis primary major Computer Science Software Engineering Department Mathematics Department, work include data science component. Data Science Program Student Outcomes Provide leadership mathematical computer science aspect use data solve related problems."}

{"source": "Electrical%20Engineering.txt", "text": "This is about Electrical Engineering txt. This is about Electrical Engineering txt. This is about Electrical Engineering txt. Electrical Engineering\n\nElectrical Engineering (EE) is a professional engineering discipline that deals with the study and application of electricity, electronics, and electromagnetism. Common EE tasks include designing communication systems, energy conversion and power delivery, control systems applications, design of analog and digital systems, and others. ", "lemma": "Electrical Engineering Electrical Engineering (EE) be professional engineering discipline deal study application electricity, electronics, electromagnetism. Common EE task include design communication systems, energy conversion power delivery, control system applications, design analog digital systems, others."}
{"source": "Electrical%20Engineering.txt", "text": "This is about Electrical Engineering txt. This is about Electrical Engineering txt. This is about Electrical Engineering txt. Below is a recommended plan of study for EE.\n\nEE Program Educational Objectives\n\nElectrical Engineering graduates shall:\n\nPractice excellence in their profession using a systems approach encompassing technological, economic, ethical, environmental, social, and human issues within a changing global environment;\n\nFunction independently and in leadership positions within multidisciplinary teams;\n\nContinue life-long learning by acquiring new knowledge, mastering emerging technologies, and using\u00a0 appropriate tools and methods;\n\nAdapt and independently extend their learning to excel in fields about which they are passionate;\n\nStrengthen teams and communities through collaboration, effective communication, public service, and leadership.\n\nEE Student Learning Outcomes\n\nAt the time of graduation, students will have demonstrated:\n\nan ability to identify, formulate, and solve complex engineering problems by applying principles of engineering, science, and mathematics\n\nan ability to apply engineering design to produce solutions that meet specified needs with consideration of public health, safety, welfare, as well as global, cultural, social, environmental, and economic factors\n\nan ability to communicate effectively with a range of audiences\n\nan ability to recognize ethical and professional responsibilities in engineering situations and make informed judgments, which must consider the impact of engineering solutions in global, economic, environmental, and societal contexts\n\nan ability to function effectively on a team whose members together provide leadership, create a collaborative and inclusive environment, establish goals, plan tasks, and meet objectives\n\nan ability to develop and conduct appropriate experimentation, analyze and interpret data, and use engineering judgment to draw conclusions\n\nan ability to acquire and apply new knowledge as needed, using appropriate learning strategies.\n\nThe electrical engineering program is accredited by the Engineering Accreditation Commission of ABET, https://www.abet.org, under the commission\u2019s General Criteria and Program Criteria for Electrical, Computer, Communications, Telecommunication(s), and Similarly Named Engineering Programs.\n\n", "lemma": "Below be recommended plan study EE. EE Student Learning Outcomes time graduation, student have demonstrated: ability identify, formulate, solve complex engineering problem apply principle engineering, science, mathematics ability apply engineering design produce solution meet specified need consideration public health, safety, welfare, as well global, cultural, social, environmental, economic factor ability communicate effectively range audience ability recognize ethical professional responsibility engineering situation make inform judgments, consider impact engineering solution global, economic, environmental, societal context ability function effectively team member together provide leadership, create collaborative inclusive environment, establish goals, plan tasks, meet objective ability develop conduct appropriate experimentation, analyze interpret data, use engineering judgment draw conclusion ability acquire apply new knowledge needed, use appropriate learning strategies. electrical engineering program be accredit Engineering Accreditation Commission ABET, https://www.abet.org, commission\u2019s General Criteria Program Criteria Electrical, Computer, Communications, Telecommunication(s), Similarly Named Engineering Programs."}

Students also work with external clients starting in their first quarter on campus.\n\nEngineering Design\n\nEngineering design is a human-centered endeavor that grew out of investigations of creativity.\u00a0 While design is an integral part of all engineering fields, design methodology gained more attention during the 1980s as global competition demanded higher quality design and system complexity increased. The role of the designer is to create a system, process, product, or service based on stakeholder needs while considering social, environmental, economic, and safety requirements. The designer must have both a mindset and skillset for improving the impact of design on society. ", "lemma": "Students also work external client start first quarter campus. The skillset includes the tools and techniques critical to realize the design.\n\nThe Engineering Design major prepares students by giving them repeated, intensive design experiences with real clients. From the first quarter to the senior year, students participate in authentic design experiences and practice professional skills. The first year gives students a broad understanding of modeling systems across disciplines and repeated practice in prototyping solutions for clients. Students select a concentration and prepare for their practicum as they continue deeper in the design process. Second year students also learn the process of on-boarding into existing projects as they work with seniors one quarter and freshmen another. {"source": "General%20Education.txt", "text": "This is about General Education txt. This is about General Education txt. This is about General Education txt. General Education\n\nAs a specialized institution with a focus on science, engineering, and mathematics, Rose-Hulman approaches Institute-wide general education differently than most schools. In fact, we seldom use the term \u201cgeneral education,\u201d although our programs still seek to provide each student with a broad liberal education that complements their technical disciplines.\n\nEach student will complete, as a part of their program, at least 36 credit hours in the humanities, social sciences, and arts (HSSA). Additionally, due to the technical nature of our programs, students will complete over 35 credit hours of foundational math and science courses. Students will also complete RHIT 100 \u2013 Foundations for Rose-Hulman Success.\n\nIn total, this equates to 72 credit hours (54 equivalent semester credit hours) of what would typically be included in a general education program. Student learning is systematically reviewed as part of Rose-Hulman\u2019s assessment and continuous improvement practices at both the institute and program levels. ", "lemma": "General Education specialized institution focus science, engineering, mathematics, Rose-Hulman approach Institute-wide general education differently most schools. fact, seldom term \u201cgeneral program still seek provide student broad liberal education complement technical disciplines. student complete, part program, least credit hour humanities, social sciences, art (HSSA). Additionally, due technical nature programs, student complete credit hour foundational math science courses. Students also complete RHIT \u2013 Foundations Rose-Hulman Success. total, equate credit hour (54 equivalent semester credit hours) typically be include general education program. Student learning be systematically review part Rose-Hulman\u2019s assessment continuous improvement practice institute program levels."}

Humanities, Social Sciences, AND THE ARTS\n\nAREAS OF STUDY\n\nSee Thematic Categories, below.\n\nMAJORS\n\nInternational Studies (second major only)\n\nCertificates\n\nInternational Studies\n\nMINORS\n\nAnthropology\n\nArt\n\nCognitive Science\n\nEast Asian Studies\n\nEconomics\n\nEuropean Studies\n\nGeography\n\nGerman\n\nHistory\n\nJapanese\n\nLanguage and Literature\n\nLatin American Studies\n\nMusic\n\nPolitical Science\n\nPhilosophy and Religion\n\nPsychology\n\nSpanish\n\nTheatre and Drama\n\nMISSION STATEMENT\n\nTo enable our students to become creative, sophisticated thinkers, active citizens, and effective leaders in the global community, the department contributes to a broad liberal education, introducing students to a wide array of disciplines and traditions in the humanities and social sciences. In doing so, it provides learning experiences that, in addition to their intrinsic value, enrich a scientific and technical education.\n\nEducational Objectives\n\nWithin the context of a liberal education, the department fosters in its students the desire and the ability to:\n\nthink critically, forming cogent, informed opinions, defining and solving problems with an awareness that societal processes are complex and interactive;\n\ncommunicate effectively\u00a0to diverse audiences, including those from other cultures and communities;\n\nsucceed in a global context\u00a0by understanding and adapting to diverse cultures, alternative points of view, and the challenges of globalization;\n\nexhibit ethical and responsible leadership\u00a0as individuals, citizens, and professionals, committed to lifelong learning and achievement.\n\nAREAS OF STUDY\n\nThe following disciplines are represented within the department:\n\nHumanities & Arts (H) Social Sciences (S) Modern Languages (L) Arts (ARTS) Anthropology (ANTH) German (GER) English (ENGL) Economics (ECON) Japanese (JAPN) History (HIST) Geography (GEOG) Spanish (SPAN) Music (MUSI) Political Science (POLS) Philosophy (PHIL) Psychology (PSYC) Religion (RELG) Multidisciplinary areas within the Humanities (HUM) Multidisciplinary areas within the Social Sciences (SOC)\n\nGraduation Requirements\n\n1. General\n\nAll students must take a minimum of nine courses (36 credits) in Humanities, Social Sciences, and the Arts (HSSA). These courses may be chosen from the HSSA offerings, within the restrictions below.\n\nStudents must take a course in at least two of the three areas of study (Humanities & Arts, Social Sciences, and Modern Languages).\n\n", "lemma": "Humanities, Social Sciences, THE ARTS AREAS OF STUDY See Thematic Categories, below. This is about Humanities  Social Sciences  and the Arts txt. This is about Humanities  Social Sciences  and the Arts txt. Technical and Professional Communication is a requirement for most majors, and counts toward the total requirement of 9 HSSA courses.\n\nModern Language\n\nStudents who elect to take a modern language should note the following special requirements:\n\nA minimum of two terms of the same language (or the equivalent thereof) must be completed in order to apply modern language credits toward Humanities and Social Sciences requirements. If only SPAN L111, JAPN L111 or GER L111 is completed, that course will not be allowed to satisfy an HSSA requirement. \u00a0For transfer credit, a single modern language course at 4 credit hours may be used to satisfy an HSSA requirement if it is higher than the entry level course (L111) in that language. Example: Transfer credit awarded for SPAN L113 could be used to satisfy one HSSA course requirement.\n\nHSSA credit will not be awarded for a lower-level language course until the student takes and passes the next course in the language sequence with a grade of C or better.\n\nNo more than 16 credits of modern language may be counted toward HSSA requirements.\n\nStudents may not earn modern language credit in their native languages.\n\nNote: Students planning to study abroad should be sure to have their program approved ahead of time by the head of the HSSA Department and by the head of the Department in which they are majoring.\n\nMinors \r\r\nStudents may elect a minor in most of the HSSA Department's disciplines. {"source": "Humanities,%20Social%20Sciences,%20and%20the%20Arts.txt", "text": "This is about Humanities  Social Sciences  and the Arts txt. This is about Humanities  Social Sciences  and the Arts txt. This is about Humanities  Social Sciences  and the Arts txt. ENGL H241 IIntroduction to Film Studies 3R-3L-4C\n\nCovers the formal elements of film and provides a vocabulary for analyzing film. Introduces film theory and criticism.\n\nENGL H243 Survey of American Literature 4R-OL-4C\n\nStudies a broad range of American literature since the Civil War. Examines a variety of authors and genres (fiction, poetry, prose, nonfiction).\n\nENGL H245 Modern World Literature 4R-OL-4C\n\nFocuses on a variety of authors and texts that respond to the world-changing events occurring at the height of imperialism, world wars, and national independence movements across the globe.\n\nENGL H290 Technical & Professional Communication 4R-OL-4C F, W, S\n\nProvides students with instruction and practice in analyzing contexts, audiences, and genres; crafting documents to meet the demands and constraints of professional situations; integrating all stages of the writing process; and collaborating effectively within and across teams.\n\nENGL H330 Contemporary Global Film 3R-3L-4C\n\nExamines films outside of the Hollywood tradition with a consideration of the cultural, political, and economic influences that shape film.\n\nENGL H331 Irish Drama 4R-0L-4C\n\nSurveys Irish drama from about 1900 to the present.\n\nENGL H332 American Modernism 4R-OL-4C\n\nExplores texts published in the first half of the twentieth century, what is commonly called the \"Modernist\" era. Focuses primarily on written works in different genres, but also covers music, film, visual arts, and other media.\n\nENGL H333 Creative Writing 4R-OL-4C\n\nIntroduces students to writing in genres such as poetry, short fiction, literary nonfiction, and drama. Employs a variety of writing and revision techniques to assist students in producing a portfolio of their work.\n\nENGL H334 Travel in World Literature 4R-OL-4C\n\nExamines a wide variety of literature\u2013including some in translation\u2013and emphasizes works that comment on travel, tourism, and the effects of colonialism.\n\nENGL H335 Reading the Bible 4R-OL-4C\n\nExamines the Hebrew Bible and the New Testament as literary texts. Emphasizes the variety of genres employed in biblical literature and introduces students to different approaches appropriate to literary interpretation.\n\nENGL H336 Mystery & Horror Literature 4R-OL-4C\n\nExamines the development, contexts, generic conventions, and social functions of modern horror and detective fiction from their roots in European Gothic traditions to the present.\n\nENGL H337 Romanticism 4R-OL-4C\n\nCovers major authors and themes in European Romantic literature from 1770-1830, as well as its repercussions and transformations.\n\nENGL H338 Banned in the USA 4R-OL-4C\n\nExplores frequently challenged or banned works of American literature. Choosing themes that interest them, students cultivate scholarly skills and habits that will serve them throughout their college careers and beyond: considering diverse perspectives; reading for deep and nuanced understanding; exploring research questions with an open mind; engaging with others' ideas while developing their own; writing for specific audiences and purposes; revising existing writing to incorporate feedback and new information; and crafting well-supported, appealing arguments.\n\nPrerequisite Notes:\r\r\n                \n\nHUM H199 Introduction to International Studies 4R-OL-4C S\n\nIntroduces International Studies as an interdisciplinary field of inquiry and scholarship. Students will explore multiple disciplines in the humanities, social sciences, and arts, applying their analytical and interpretive frameworks to global regions, cultural institutions, and sociohistorical processes important to today's world events and contemporary debates. As an inherently interdisciplinary course, Introduction to International Studies can be taken for either humanities (H) or social science (S) credit. PHIL H101 Introduction to Philosophy 4R-OL-4C\n\nIntroduces the student to the methods and subject matter of philosophy through a selective consideration of fundamental philosophical problems such as the nature of reality, the existence of God, the criteria of knowing, and the basis of morality.\n\nPHIL H102 Critical Thinking and Introduction to Logic 4R-OL-4C\n\nIntroduces students to philosophical methodology for examining the truth of claims and the quality of arguments\r\r\nused to defend them, including informal logic, i.e., the study of arguments in natural language, as well as formal\r\r\nlogic, i.e., the study of inference with purely formal content, for the purpose of clarifying thinking and improving\r\r\nreasoning.\n\nPHIL H201 Bioethics 4R-OL-4C\n\nExamines the major moral issues in the development and practice of biomedicine and biomedical research through the analysis of philosophical and ethical theory as well as analysis of real cases of morally questionable practice in biomedicine. Topics include the autonomy and rights of patients, physicians, and researchers, informed consent and experimentation with humans and animals, the moral status of genetic and reproductive controls and interventions, the extension and termination of life, and the allocation of scarce medical resources.\n\nPHIL H202 Business & Engineering Ethics 4R-OL-4C\n\nExamines the ethical issues faced by professional businesspeople and engineers working in a global corporate context. Issues include the development and use of codes of professional ethics, the social responsibilities of corporations, the autonomy of professionals, whistleblowing and corporate loyalty, environmental obligations of corporations and professionals, standards of conduct in international business, and the impact of technology on our world.\n\nPHIL H301 Philosophy of Religion 4R-OL-4C\n\nExamines the basic philosophical problems found in religion. {"source": "International%20Computer%20Science.txt", "text": "This is about International Computer Science txt. This is about International Computer Science txt. This is about International Computer Science txt. The lifetime of a particular computer system or software package can be very short. The international computer science curriculum is designed to prepare students for multiple careers in a rapidly changing, global environment. The program\u2019s courses emphasize fundamental concepts and techniques that will last longer than present technology.\n\nInternational computer science majors complete a core of basic computer science courses that includes the study of algorithms, data structures, database concepts, computer systems, computer architecture, programming languages, operating systems, and software engineering. Advanced courses in theory of computation, computer networks, distributed systems, security, and real time systems add depth to the degree program. A three-term senior thesis provides students the opportunity to research in depth an area of computer science that is of interest to them under the mentorship of a faculty member. Majors also complete important courses in closely related fields, e.g., discrete mathematics and probability and statistics, as well as study a foreign language. The major requires students to study all aspects of the science of computing, including hardware, software, and theory.\n\nFive free electives allow students to tailor their undergraduate education to their specific goals and pursue topics of interest to them. Students may choose to do advanced elective work in computer science and software engineering and/or in the humanities and social sciences, and/or pursue a minor or double major in another discipline.\n\nProgramming assignments and large projects are part of most computer science courses. The national computer science honor society, Upsilon Pi Epsilon, has chartered its Indiana Alpha Chapter at Rose-Hulman; it sponsors several seminars throughout the year.\n\nInternational Computer Science Program Educational Objectives\n\nGraduates from the international computer science program will be prepared for many types of careers in the field of computing and prepared for graduate study in computer science and in closely related disciplines. In the early phases of their careers, we expect Rose-Hulman international computer science graduates to be:\n\nComputing professionals in a variety of organizations, including ones doing traditional software development, technological innovation, and cross-disciplinary work\n\nBusiness and technological leaders within existing organizations\n\nEntrepreneurial leaders\n\nRecognized by their peers and superiors for their communication, teamwork, and leadership skills\n\nActively involved in social and professional service locally, nationally, and globally\n\nGraduate students and researchers\n\nLeaders in government and law as government employees, policy makers, governmental advisors, and legal professionals\n\nInternational Computer Science Student Outcomes\n\nBy the time scalability\n\nAnalyze algorithms in terms of correctness, as well as time and space efficiency\n\nEvaluate and discuss the legal, social, and ethical aspects of significant events that arise in the {"source": "Mathematics.txt", "text": "This is about Mathematics txt. This is about Mathematics txt. This is about Mathematics txt. Mathematics\n\nWhy study mathematics? Many of the new wonders that we take for granted in our modern technological society have mathematical ideas and applications as their basis, though this role is often hidden from view. Complex economic and planning decisions, scientific discoveries that improve our lives, and new technologies and products are often possible only after mathematical or statistical analysis, or a computer visualization, simulation, design and implementation based on mathematics. Therefore, mathematicians, as well as mathematically educated scientists, engineers and economists, make important daily contributions in the understanding and advancement of science, the improvement and discovery of new technology, and decision-making and planning in business, industry and government. Students interested in using their mathematical skills in solving real world problems are well prepared, by majoring or minoring in mathematics, for careers such as in the insurance industry, software design, data and systems analysis, scientific computing, combustion research, the animated movie industry, and cryptanalysis to name a few, or a graduate degree in a related technical field. Those students with a very strong interest in mathematics itself can pursue graduate study in mathematics in preparation for careers as university or college mathematics teachers and in the development of new mathematical and statistical concepts and methods as researchers in academia, government and industry.\n\nThe curriculum of the program in the Department of Mathematics is designed to provide a broad education in both theoretical and applied mathematics. It also develops the scientific knowledge and the problem solving, computing, and communications skills that are critical to a successful mathematically based career. This preparation is greatly enhanced by taking advantage of the wide variety of science and engineering courses available to students and developing good communications skills, both through technical courses and the strong humanities program. The program offers a solid grounding in the foundational areas of calculus, differential equations, linear algebra, discrete and combinatorial algebra, and probability and statistics. These basic courses are complemented by a varied selection of upper division courses for further elective study in areas such as numerical analysis, operations research, advanced statistics, mathematical modeling, optimization, and other advanced topics in mathematics. Students are encouraged to develop a strong background in an area of science or engineering through election of courses leading to a minor or double major. By appropriate course selection students may complete a double major in mathematics and another field such as computer science, physics, chemistry, applied biology, or economics.\n\nPROGRAM GOALS AND OBJECTIVES\n\nTo provide a foundation for further learning as well as contributing to the general education of students, the programs at Rose-Hulman all have a heavy investment in mathematics and science in the first two years. The freshman and sophomore mathematics curriculum is designed to contribute to this foundation by ensuring that students are familiar with basic mathematical and statistical concepts, and mathematical and statistical reasoning and modeling. ", "lemma": "Mathematics study mathematics? Many new wonder take grant modern technological society have mathematical idea application basis, role be often hide view. Complex economic plan decisions, scientific discovery improve lives, new technology product be often possible only mathematical statistical analysis, computer visualization, simulation, design implementation base mathematics. Therefore, mathematicians, as well mathematically educate scientists, engineer economists, make important daily contribution understanding advancement science, improvement discovery new technology, decision-making planning business, industry government. Students interested use mathematical skill solve real world problem be well prepared, major minoring mathematics, career such insurance industry, software design, data system analysis, scientific computing, combustion research, animated movie industry, cryptanalysis name few, graduate degree related technical field. student very strong interest mathematics pursue graduate study mathematics preparation career university college mathematics teacher development new mathematical statistical concept method researcher academia, government industry. curriculum program Department Mathematics be design provide broad education theoretical applied mathematics. also develop scientific knowledge problem solving, computing, communication skill be critical successful mathematically base career. preparation be greatly enhance take advantage wide variety science engineering course available student develop good communication skills, technical course strong humanity program. program offer solid grounding foundational area calculus, differential equations, linear algebra, discrete combinatorial algebra, probability statistics. basic course be complement varied selection upper division course further elective study area such numerical analysis, operation research, advanced statistics, mathematical modeling, optimization, other advanced topic mathematics. Students be encourage develop strong background area science engineering election course lead minor double major. appropriate course selection student complete double major mathematics field such computer science, physics, chemistry, apply biology, economics. PROGRAM GOALS AND OBJECTIVES provide foundation further learning as well contribute general education program Rose-Hulman have heavy investment mathematics science first years. freshman sophomore mathematics curriculum be design contribute foundation ensure student be familiar basic mathematical statistical concepts, mathematical statistical reasoning modeling."}

{"source": "Mathematics.txt", "text": "This is about Mathematics txt. This is about Mathematics txt. This is about Mathematics txt. In addition, students will learn to be competent users of mathematics, especially in problem solving, and be able to effectively communicate mathematically. The curriculum makes strong use of computer methods to develop students\u2019 mathematical understanding and to enhance their ability to use the computer in modeling, computation and problem solving.\n\nFor students seeking a major in mathematics, the curriculum prepares them for a mathematically based career after graduation or further graduate study. The major builds upon the goals and objectives of the freshman and sophomore curriculum. In addition to a deeper and broader study of mathematics, majors will further develop their ability to formulate and solve problems from a mathematical perspective, become familiar with the use of mathematics in other fields, and develop competence at the application of mathematics to at least one other field. Graduates will also be able to use technology effectively in mathematics and the application of mathematics. To complement these technical skills graduates will learn the professional skills of effective communication with both technical and non-technical audiences and the ability to work cooperatively with others.\n\nMathematics Program Goals and Student Learning Outcomes\n\nMathematics majors should be able to meet the following Student Learning Outcomes\n\nGoal 1:\u00a0 Students will learn the fundamental principles underlying the major areas of mathematics\n\nSLO 1.1.\u00a0 Perform calculations and prove statements about objects, morphisms, and structure theorems in vector spaces and abstract algebra.\n\n", "lemma": "addition, student learn be competent user mathematics, especially problem solving, be able effectively communicate mathematically. curriculum make strong use computer method develop students\u2019 mathematical understanding enhance ability use computer modeling, computation problem solving. student seek major mathematics, curriculum prepare mathematically base career graduation further graduate study. major build goal objective freshman sophomore curriculum. addition deep broad study mathematics, major far develop ability formulate solve problem mathematical perspective, become familiar use mathematics other fields, develop competence application mathematics least other field. {"source": "Mathematics.txt", "text": "This is about Mathematics txt. This is about Mathematics txt. This is about Mathematics txt. Generalize properties of numbers and functions to other algebraic, analytic, topological, or geometric structures.\n\nDEGREE REQUIREMENTS\n\nMajor Concentrations:\u00a0Mathematics majors choose to complete their program in one of four concentrations: Mathematics, Continuous Applied Mathematics, Discrete Applied Mathematics, or Statistics and Operations Research. The Mathematics concentration provides the foundational mathematical depth of a traditional mathematics major and is intended for students planning on graduate study in an area of mathematics. In applied mathematics there are two areas: the Continuous Applied Mathematics concentration and the Discrete Applied Mathematics concentration. Students selecting these concentrations may tailor their programs to interface with another major or to enhance industrial employment or graduate school opportunities. The Statistics and Operations Research concentration is recommended for students pursuing careers in actuarial science, graduate study in statistics, or employment in government or industry in a statistical capacity. It is strongly recommended that students considering graduate education in mathematics include MA 376 Abstract Algebra among their elective mathematics courses. {"source": "Mathematics.txt", "text": "This is about Mathematics txt. This is about Mathematics txt. This is about Mathematics txt. Upon graduation a student may request the Head of the Mathematics Department to issue a letter attesting to the fact that the requirements in the chosen concentration have been completed.\n\nMathematics Coursework Requirements:\u00a0All mathematics majors must complete a common core consisting of 39 credit hours of mathematics coursework, which provides breadth across the main areas of mathematics. A mathematics major must also complete an additional 12 credit hours of mathematics coursework specified for the selected major concentration plus an additional 12 credit hours earned in free elective mathematics or biomathematics courses. A mathematics major must additionally complete an 8-credit hour capstone experience. A total of 71 credit hours of mathematics courses is required for the major. None of the credits in the 71 hours above may be taken from the courses MA190, MA351-MA356, MA450 or MA223 (unless approved by the department head). These courses (except MA190) may be taken as free electives. {"source": "Mathematics.txt", "text": "This is about Mathematics txt. This is about Mathematics txt. This is about Mathematics txt. Note that MA491 may replace 2 hours of MA496 and that MA497 and MA498 must be taken in separate terms. The capstone is an important experience for the mathematics major, representing a sustained effort to solve a complex problem in the mathematical sciences. The Senior Capstone must involve significant individual work, and it must culminate with both a written report and an oral presentation. Both the report and the presentation must be submitted to the department. \u00a0\n\nStudents double majoring in mathematics and another program who complete the senior project courses for that program must also complete MA491 for the senior project to satisfy the Senior Capstone requirement within the mathematics major.\u00a0 Students double majoring in mathematics and another program who complete the senior thesis courses for that program can directly use those courses to satisfy the Senior Capstone requirement within the mathematics major. The Mathematics Capstone does not constitute a culminating major engineering design experience for students also majoring in an ABET accredited program.\n\nSummary of Requirements Mathematics Coursework - core, concentration and electives (MA351-MA356, MA450, BMTH496-498 not allowed) 63 hrs. It requires 72 credit hours, including a 52 credit hour core and a 20 credit hour specialization. The courses used to satisfy the requirements in the Advanced Core may not be counted toward any other major or minor. Notes and Limitations on Requirements\n\nAlmost all students are required to take either MA223 or MA381 as a requirement for their major; therefore, only five \u201cextra courses\u201d are required for most students.\n\nOnly one of MA223, MA381, or MA382 can be counted towards any combination of the multiple minors offered by the mathematics department.\n\nMathematics majors or biomathematics majors must have at least 16 credit hours of separation between their major and this minor.\n\nNo student can take both MA223 and MA382 for credit.\n\n", "lemma": "Notes Limitations Requirements Almost student be require take MA223 MA381 requirement major; only \u201cextra courses\u201d be require most students. {"source": "Mechanical%20Engineering.txt", "text": "This is about Mechanical Engineering txt. This is about Mechanical Engineering txt. This is about Mechanical Engineering txt. Mechanical Engineering\n\nMechanical engineering is a broad field of endeavor with opportunities in many areas of industry: production and manufacturing; aeronautics and aerospace; robotics and automation; conventional and renewable energy; automotive and transportation; and many others. Additional opportunities for mechanical engineers include careers in government, education, and private consulting. The mechanical engineering curriculum is designed to prepare students for this wide range of options by providing them with a strong foundation in the fundamental principles of science and engineering to tackle the complex technological problems of today and adapt for the challenges of tomorrow.\n\nThe required courses of the undergraduate mechanical engineering curriculum provide the basic mathematical and scientific fundamentals underlying the practice of mechanical engineering. Technical, free, and math/science elective courses allow the student flexibility in adapting the program to their interests in pursuit of their specific career goals. Electives in the humanities, social sciences, and the arts help to foster the links between society and engineering so that the mechanical engineering graduate is aware of the roles of engineering and science in solving complex technological and social problems as well as of the impacts of social and environmental factors on engineering activities such as design. For those undergraduates who choose to continue their education at Rose-Hulman, graduate work leading to a Master of Science in Mechanical Engineering or a Master of Engineering in Mechanical Engineering is offered by the department.\n\nMission: To provide the curriculum, the educational environment, and the individual support necessary to graduate mechanical engineers who are technically competent, effective in practice, creative, ethical, and mindful of their responsibility to society.\n\n", "lemma": "Mechanical Engineering Mechanical engineering be broad field endeavor opportunity many area industry: production manufacturing; aeronautics aerospace; robotics automation; conventional renewable energy; automotive transportation; many others. Additional opportunity mechanical engineer include career government, education, private consulting. mechanical engineering curriculum be design prepare student wide range option provide strong foundation fundamental principle science engineering tackle complex technological problem today adapt challenge tomorrow. required course undergraduate mechanical engineering curriculum provide basic mathematical scientific fundamental underlie practice mechanical engineering. Technical, free, math/science elective course allow student flexibility adapt program interest pursuit specific career goals. Electives humanities, social sciences, art help foster link society engineering so mechanical engineering graduate be aware role engineering science solve complex technological social problem as well impact social environmental factor engineering activity such design. undergraduate choose continue education Rose-Hulman, graduate work lead Master Science Mechanical Engineering Master Engineering Mechanical Engineering be offer department. Mission: provide curriculum, educational environment, individual support necessary graduate mechanical engineer be technically competent, effective practice, creative, ethical, mindful responsibility society."}

By providing a strong foundation in the fundamental principles of science and engineering and by illuminating the links between society and engineering, the curriculum enables students to apply what they have learned and to teach themselves new skills to address complex technological problems within the social and environmental context of our world. {"source": "Mechanical%20Engineering.txt", "text": "This is about Mechanical Engineering txt. This is about Mechanical Engineering txt. This is about Mechanical Engineering txt. The sophomore year features courses in mathematics, foundational sciences, and the engineering sciences. The final two years of the program stress the design and analysis of systems, machines and their components, and the transfer and transformation of energy. In addition to the required mathematics, science, and engineering courses, the program includes required writing and communication courses and an array of technical electives and free electives, a math/science elective, and elective courses in the humanities, social sciences, and the arts (HSSA). The requirements for an undergraduate degree in mechanical engineering are summarized in the following table:\n\nCategory Credits Required\u00a0engineering (ME, ES, EM) courses 86 Required math courses 27 Required foundational science courses 16 Required HSSA writing and communication courses 8 Required RHIT 100 course 1 Technical electives 16 Free electives 8 Math/science elective 4 HSSA electives 28 Total 194\n\nMinor in Manufacturing Engineering\n\nThe goal of this minor is to provide interested students with an opportunity to broaden their knowledge of the methods, processes and technologies related to the analysis and design of manufacturing systems.\n\nAt the completion of this minor, students will be able to:\n\nDescribe methods, processes and /or technologies used in manufacturing.\n\n", "lemma": "sophomore year feature course mathematics, foundational sciences, engineering sciences. final year program stress design analysis systems, machine components, transfer transformation energy. addition required mathematics, science, engineering courses, program include require writing communication course array technical elective free electives, math/science elective, elective course humanities, social sciences, art (HSSA). requirement undergraduate degree mechanical engineering be summarize following table: Category Credits Required engineering (ME, ES, EM) course Required math course Required foundational science course Required HSSA writing communication course Required RHIT course Technical elective Free elective Math/science elective HSSA electives Total Minor Manufacturing Engineering goal minor be provide interested student opportunity broaden knowledge methods, process technology relate analysis design manufacturing systems. completion minor, student be able to: Describe methods, process /or technology use manufacturing."}

{"source": "Mechanical%20Engineering.txt", "text": "This is about Mechanical Engineering txt. This is about Mechanical Engineering txt. This is about Mechanical Engineering txt. The Design courses provide students with expertise in the use of modern Computer-Aided Design tools to model three-dimensional shapes and to communicate these designs graphically.\u00a0 The Analysis courses explore the mathematics behind modern CAD tools, giving students a solid background in computer-aided kinematics and finite element analysis.\n\nTo earn the CAD Concentration, students must complete the following three Design classes:\n\nEM104 Graphical Communication or ENGD100 Design and Communication Studio or BE118 Design Thinking and Communication\n\nEM304 Advanced CAD \u2013 Professional Certification\n\nEM305 Advanced CAD \u2013 Parametric and Equation Driven Design\n\nIn addition, students must choose three Analysis courses from the following list\n\nME422 Finite Elements for Engineering Applications\n\nME522 Advanced Finite Element Analysis\n\nME304 Introduction to the Design of Mechanisms\n\nME404 Advanced Design of Mechanisms\n\nME480 Machine Component Design (for non-ME majors)\n\nDynamic Systems & Control Area of Concentration\n\nDynamic Systems & Control Area of Concentration\n\nTo complete the requirements of the area of concentration in This is about Mechanical Engineering txt. **28 credit hours in electives composed of 16 credit hours in technical electives, 8 credit hours in free electives, and 4 credit hours of a math elective or a science elective.\u00a0 A technical elective is any course (at the 200 level or above) in biomathematics, chemistry, computer science, engineering, engineering management, geology, mathematics, or physics that is not cross-listed with HSSA or similar in content to a required course.\u00a0 A\u00a0math elective is at the 200-level or higher and has an MA or BMTH prefix.\u00a0 A\u00a0science elective is any course in biology, chemistry, geology, or physics except those courses that are cross-listed with an engineering course.\n", "lemma": "**28 credit hour elective compose credit hour technical electives, credit hour free electives, credit hour math elective science elective. technical elective be course (at level above) biomathematics, chemistry, computer science, engineering, engineering management, geology, mathematics, physic be not cross-listed HSSA similar content required course. {"source": "NanoEngineering.txt", "text": "This is about NanoEngineering txt. This is about NanoEngineering txt. This is about NanoEngineering txt. NanoEngineering\n\nNanoEngineering emphasizes micro-nanoscale engineering courses necessary to work in areas such as semiconductor manufacturing, molecular electronics, integrated silicon photonics, nanomedicine, micro- and nano-electromechanical systems, thin film technologies, and other applications of nanotechnology. The engineering coursework is grounded in a strong foundation of mathematics and physics. This program uses multidisciplinary approaches in solving problems with a global understanding of engineering design, systems optimization, and fabrication techniques. ", "lemma": "NanoEngineering NanoEngineering emphasizes micro-nanoscale engineering course necessary work area such semiconductor manufacturing, molecular electronics, integrate silicon photonics, nanomedicine, micro- nano-electromechanical systems, thin film technologies, other application engineering coursework be ground strong foundation mathematics physics. program use multidisciplinary approach solve problem global understanding engineering design, system optimization, fabrication techniques."}
{"source": "NanoEngineering.txt", "text": "This is about NanoEngineering txt. This is about NanoEngineering txt. This is about NanoEngineering txt. Graduates will address the complex needs and challenges of cutting-edge nanotechnology using manufacturing, characterization, and analysis tools including those in a cleanroom environment. Rose-Hulman\u2019s NanoEngineering graduates are trained to take up any demanding jobs for the development of new technologies or to pursue graduate school for further studies in engineering or physics.\n\nMission:\u00a0To provide a coherent foundation of physics and cutting-edge engineering that leads to a large variety of possibilities for its graduates.\u00a0NanoEngineering graduates are trained in design, optimization, fabrication, and testing of semiconductor and nanoscale systems. Graduates are enabled to practice their dynamic and progressive engineering profession in emerging fields as responsible citizens of the global society.\n\nVision:\u00a0To cultivate in students the responsibility, independence, and knowledge that allows them to be fully engaged engineers in all disciplines, to continuously improve their knowledge and skills, and to be engaged in the development process of emerging nanotechnologies and semiconductor manufacturing.\n\nNE Program Educational Objectives\n\nBased on our mission and the needs of our constituents, our graduates will:\n\nsolve complex problems, create new knowledge, and incorporate innovative solutions.\n\nbe a good citizen of the world, participate in solving major world problems such as climate change and poverty, and develop products and policies that are ethically, socially, and economically responsible.\n\nadopt and learn new skills, engage in lifelong learning, continue developing their knowledge, and teach others the benefits and limitations of their field.\n\n", "lemma": "Graduates address complex need challenge cutting-edge nanotechnology use manufacturing, characterization, analysis tool include cleanroom environment. Rose-Hulman\u2019s NanoEngineering graduate be train take up demanding job development new technology pursue graduate school further study engineering physics. Mission: provide coherent foundation physic cutting-edge engineering lead large variety possibility graduates. NanoEngineering graduate be train design, optimization, fabrication, testing semiconductor nanoscale systems. Graduates be enable practice dynamic progressive engineering profession emerge field responsible citizen global society. Vision: cultivate student responsibility, independence, knowledge allow be fully engage engineer disciplines, continuously improve knowledge skills, be engage development process emerge nanotechnology semiconductor manufacturing. {"source": "Optical%20Engineering.txt", "text": "This is about Optical Engineering txt. This is about Optical Engineering txt. This is about Optical Engineering txt. Optical Engineering\n\nThe science of light, once confined to research labs and science fiction novels, has found its way into our everyday lives. The applications of optics can be seen everywhere. A list of more common examples of these applications include laser printers, fiber optic communication, internet switches, fiber optic telephone lines, compact disc players, credit cards bearing holograms, grocery checkout scanners, computers and eye surgery. The field of optics is an enabling technology and is growing at a rapid pace. Optical techniques are found in a wide range of areas such as surveying and construction, measurements of material parameters and deformation, flow measurements, communications, machine vision, laser cutting, drilling and welding, data storage, internet switches, optical computers and sensors etc. Surveys show that there is a growing demand for optical designers/scientists/ engineers every year. Opportunities for graduates in Optical Engineering are available in many industries, including automated inspection, consumer electronics, fiber optic communications, optical instrumentation, laser devices, radar systems, data storage etc.\n\nThe Optical Engineering bachelor\u2019s degree program is one of the few in the country. This program provides a firm foundation for those interested in continuing thier studies in optics at the graduate level, as well as for those going into industry. ", "lemma": "Optical Engineering science light, once confine research lab science fiction novels, have find way everyday lives. application optic be see list more common example application include laser printers, fiber optic communication, internet switches, fiber optic telephone lines, compact disc players, credit card bear holograms, grocery checkout scanners, computer eye surgery. field optic be enable technology be grow rapid pace. Optical technique be find wide range area such surveying construction, measurement material parameter deformation, flow measurements, communications, machine laser cutting, drilling welding, data storage, internet switches, optical computer sensor etc. Surveys show be grow demand optical designers/scientists/ engineer year. Opportunities graduate Optical Engineering be available many industries, include automated inspection, consumer electronics, fiber optic communications, optical instrumentation, laser devices, radar systems, data storage etc. Optical Engineering bachelor\u2019s degree program be few country. program provide firm foundation interested continue thier study optic graduate level, as well go industry."}
{"source": "Optical%20Engineering.txt", "text": "This is about Optical Engineering txt. This is about Optical Engineering txt. This is about Optical Engineering txt. The curriculum was developed by the faculty with input from industrial representatives as well as from renowned national and international optics educators. Because of the diverse applications of optics, the curriculum contains a mix of courses in physics and mathematics as well as humanities and social sciences. The Optical Engineering program at Rose-Hulman stresses laboratory instruction. We also encourage students to look at options for a double major, especially Optical Engineering with electrical, computer or mechanical engineering.\n\nStudents majoring in degree programs other than Optical Engineering are eligible to obtain an area minor in Optical Engineering.\n\nThe Department of Physics and Optical Engineering also offers an M.S. (Optical Engineering) degree. The masters level degree program complements the B.S. (Optical Engineering) degree program. Highly motivated students may obtain both a B.S. ", "lemma": "curriculum be develop faculty input industrial representative as well renowned national international optic educators. diverse application curriculum contain mix course physic mathematics as well humanity social sciences. {"source": "Optical%20Engineering.txt", "text": "This is about Optical Engineering txt. This is about Optical Engineering txt. This is about Optical Engineering txt. The creation of a workgroup within the faculty of both departments will coordinate current courses and resources, create new courses of interest for the field, and develop a showcase testbed education and research laboratory. Primary objectives include the removal of redundancy from existing courses, increasing interaction between the PHOE and ECE Departments, and improving opportunities for students in the field.\n\nThis certificate is designed to give the student a firm theoretical and practical working knowledge in the area of fiber optic devices, optical communications, networks and its applications. The main purpose is to couch these fundamentals in a context that serves as the backbone for device, components and sub-system development for use in high-speed optical data and information links and networks. At the end of the program the student will be expected to:\n\nUnderstand the fundamental operation characteristics of high-speed optoelectronic components, such as laser transmitters, light modulators and receivers and passive fiber optic components as connectors, couplers, filters, and switches.\n\nUnderstand the technology and performance of analog and digital fiber optic links, optical amplification and optical wavelength division multiplexing and optical time division multiplexing networks.\n\nHave hands-on working knowledge of the use of fiber optic test equipment and techniques used by industry and telecommunication companies to test the performance of optical fiber links and components, such as, optical time domain reflectometry, optical spectrum analyzers and optical bit error testing equipment.\n\nThe Certificate will consist of 20 credit hours of which 12 credit hours will be required courses. Students interested in pursuing this Certificate should contact an ECE/PHOE certificate advisor (Professors Duree, Granieri, Alisafaee, Reza, Joenathan, Siahmakoun).\n\nRequired Courses\n\nECE 310 Communication Systems\n\nOE 393 Fiber Optics and Applications\n\nOE 493 Fundamentals of Optical Fiber Communications\n\nElective Courses (two from the list)\n\nOnly courses not required for the student\u2019s major will count for electives in the certificate.\n\nECE 380 Discrete Time & Continuous Systems\n\nECE 410 Communication Networks\n\nECE 414 Wireless Systems\n\nOE 360 Optical Materials\n\nOE 435 Biomedical Optics\n\nOE 450 Laser Systems and Applications\n\nPlan of Study\n\nFreshman\n\n             \n\nOpen\n\n                    \n\n                    \n\n                        Close\n\nFall\n\nCourse Credit MA 111 Calculus I 5 PH 111 Physics I 4 RHIT 100 Foundations for Rose-Hulman Success 1 CHEM 111 General Chemistry I 4 EM 104 Graph Comm 2 Total Credits: 16\n\nWinter\n\nCourse Credit PH 112 Physics II 4 MA 112 Calculus II 5 CHEM 113 General Chemistry II 4 HUM H190 First-Year Writing Seminar 4 Total Credits: 17\n\nSpring\n\nCourse Credit PH 113 Physics III 4 MA 113 Calculus III 5 ME 123 Computer Applications I or CSSE 120 Intro to Soft Dev 4 OE 172 Lasers & Fiber Optics * 2 EM 103 Intro Eng. Physics\n\nThe physics curriculum is designed to develop a strong foundation in classical and modern physics, which will serve as a basis for future specialization, for additional study at the graduate level, and for design and development work in industrial laboratories. The curriculum emphasizes basic physical concepts, and includes extensive work in mathematics and related areas. ", "lemma": "Physics physic curriculum be design develop strong foundation classical modern physics, serve basis future specialization, additional study graduate level, design development work industrial laboratories. curriculum emphasize basic physical concepts, include extensive work mathematics related areas."}

Laboratory facilities are available for work in optics, acoustics, X-ray diffraction, nuclear physics, and solid-state physics. {"source": "Physics.txt", "text": "This is about Physics txt. This is about Physics txt. This is about Physics txt. The students have the opportunity to take a variety of courses in disciplines such as math and chemistry allowing them to tailor their education. The Physics curriculum is flexible enough that one can double major in computer science, mathematics, electrical engineering, and mechanical engineering. National interest in our program has been generated by our basic physics courses that use new methodologies of teaching such as studio format lectures.\n\nWe have a wide range of research programs accessible to undergraduates including areas such as: Astronomy, Solid State Devices, Electro-optics, Non-linear Optics, X-ray absorption, Semiconductor Materials and Devices, Magnetics, Chaos, Lasers, Fiber Optics, Holography, Microsensors. In addition, we are very successful in placing our students in summer internship positions with various research facilities such as NASA, Argonne National Laboratory, Sandia National Laboratory, National Radio Astronomy Observatory, and CSPAAR.\n\nPhysics Student Learning Outcomes\n\nFundamental Knowledge: Demonstrate a broad working knowledge base in physics.\n\nProblem Solving: Demonstrate competency in applying the skills and knowledge necessary for scientific solutions to mathematical, scientific, and engineering problems.\n\nExperiments: Design and conduct experiments and interpret and analyze acquired data while demonstrating understanding of the underlying scientific theory, method, and process.\n\n", "lemma": "student have opportunity take variety course discipline such math chemistry allow tailor education. Physics curriculum be flexible enough double major computer science, mathematics, electrical engineering, mechanical engineering. National interest program have be generate basic physic course use new methodology teach such studio format lectures. have wide range research program accessible undergraduate include area such as: Astronomy, Solid State Devices, Electro-optics, Non-linear Optics, X-ray absorption, Semiconductor Materials Devices, Magnetics, Chaos, Lasers, Fiber Optics, Holography, Microsensors. addition, be very successful place student summer internship position various research facility such NASA, Argonne National Laboratory, Sandia National Laboratory, National Radio Astronomy Observatory, CSPAAR. Problem Solving: Demonstrate competency apply skill knowledge necessary scientific solution mathematical, scientific, engineering problems. CERTIFICATE IN SEMICONDUCTOR MATERIALS AND DEVICES\n\nThe Certificate will consist of 20 credit hours of which 12 credit hours will be required courses. Students interested in pursuing this Certificate should see a PHOE certificate advisor ( S. Kirkpatrick, Liptak, McInerney, Siahmakoun, Syed and Wagner).\u00a0Students taking solid state/material science minor cannot take this certificate.\n\nRequired Courses\n\nPH405 Semiconductor Materials and Applications -- 3R-3L-4C F Pre: PH113 or PH255 or PH265 or consent of instructor.\n\nEP406 Semiconductor Devices and Fabrication -- 3R-3L-4C W Pre: PH405 or consent of instructor.\n\nEP410 Intro to MEMS: Fabrication and Applications -- 3R-3L-4C S Pre: JR or SR standing or consent of the instructor.\u00a0 \u00a0\u00a0 or: CHE440 Process Control 4R-0L-4C W Pre: CHE202\n\nElectives\n\nCourse Hours Course Title OE 450 4 Laser Systems and Applications OE 485 4 Electro-Optics and Applications PH 330 4 Material Failure PH 401 4 Introduction to Quantum Mechanics PH 440 4 X-rays and Crystalline Materials EP 408 4 Microsensors EP 411 4 Advanced Topics in MEMS ECE 351 4 Analog Electronics ECE 551 4 Digital Integrated Circuit Design ECE 552 4 Analog Integrated Circuit Design ME 302 4 Heat Transfer ME 328 4 Materials Engineering ME 424 4 Composite Materials & Mechanics ME 415 4 Corrosion and Engineering Materials CHE 314 4 Heat Transfer CHE 315 4 Material Science and Engineering CHE 440 4 Process Control CHE 441 4 Polymer Engineering CHEM 441 4 Inorganic Chemistry I CHEM 451 4 Organic Structure Determination CHEM 457 4 Synthetic Polymer Chemistry CHEM 462 4 Physical Polymer Chemistry MA 381 4 Intro to Probability with Applications to Statistics MA 385 4 Quality Methods MA 487 4 Design of Experiments\n\nOverall aim of the Certificate\n\nA certificate holder will understand how semiconductor devices work, have practical experience in the main stages of device production, have practical experience in the more common forms of device testing and characterization, and have broad understanding of the mechanical and chemical properties of the material used.\n\nA Certificate holder will be well suited for jobs requiring an understanding of semiconductor devices and their production. {"source": "Pre-Professional.txt", "text": "This is about Pre Professional txt. This is about Pre Professional txt. This is about Pre Professional txt. Pre-Professional Programs & Advising\n\nMany graduates of Rose-Hulman choose to pursue professional or graduate studies after completion of their undergraduate studies. Engineering and science curricula provide excellent backgrounds for careers in business, law, and medicine. Pre-medicine Advising\n\nBecause of the increased importance of engineering and instrumentation technology in modern medicine, medical schools are very interested in attracting superior students with engineering and science backgrounds. The various curricula at Rose-Hulman, when supplemented with elective courses available, enable the student to meet all course requirements for admission to medical school.\n\nEach medical school has its own specific minimum academic requirements but the generally include basic courses in general chemistry, physics, organic chemistry, and biology. Programs in biology, biomedical engineering, biochemistry, chemistry and chemical engineering provide especially helpful backgrounds for this purpose, but many Rose-Hulman graduates from a variety of disciplines such as mathematics, physics, mechanical engineering, and electrical engineering, have completed medical school and are successful practicing physicians.\n\nApplication to a medical school should be made between May and October of the year previous to that in which the applicant expects to enter. ROTC: Air Force\n\nAir Force ROTC is designed as a four year training program that culminates in a student's becoming an Officer in the United States Air Force. This program is designed to run concurrently with the four year college curriculum and is open to all college students at no obligation.*\n\nWe also offer modified programs which can be completed in three or two years which also earn a commission in the Air Force. Once students have completed Air Force ROTC and college requirements they are off to serve at least the next four years in leadership positions throughout the Air Force.\n\nBased on individual situations, Air Force ROTC will ask for an obligation before more advanced training or monies are paid to a student. Until such time, the classes are free and at no obligation-contact Air Force ROTC for more details.\n\nSCHOLARSHIPS\n\nThe Air Force is looking for the best and brightest students the country has to offer. ROTC: Army\n\nThe completion of the Army ROTC program leads to a commission as a Second Lieutenant in the Active Army, Army Reserve or Army National Guard. Students completing the program receive their commissions upon graduation and serve a specified period of active duty ranging from three months to four years, depending upon the student\u2019s choice of commissioning program and Army requirements.\n\nCURRICULUM\n\nThe ROTC program specializes in teaching leadership and management skills required by the military and sought by civilian employers. ROTC cadets learn how to motivate co-workers and how to plan, organize and implement large projects and tasks. They also learn skills in demand in civilian businesses, such as teamwork, tact problem solving, decision making, and effective communication. The program includes the Basic Course for freshmen and sophomores and the Advanced Course for juniors and seniors. Allowances\n\nUniforms are furnished, when appropriate, to all students without charge. Students on scholarship and/or enrolled in the Advanced Course receive a monthly subsistence allowance that ranges from $250-400 per month during the school year and approximately $20 per day during the ROTC Advanced Camp, plus free room and board (meals).\n\nScholarships\n\nROTC awards Full-Tuition scholarships plus free Room/Board per year, providing money for tuition and educational fees. Scholarships are awarded strictly on merit, although the Institute provides an additional financial incentive. Scholarship winners also receive a designated textbook allowance of $900 per year and a tax-free stipend allowance from $300-500 per month for up to 10 months for each year the scholarship is in effect.
