{"source": "Software%20Engineering.txt", "text": "This is about Software Engineering txt. This is about Software Engineering txt. This is about Software Engineering txt. Software Engineering\n\nSoftware engineering is the creation of software using a process similar to other engineering disciplines. It allows for software to be reliable and developed within time and cost estimates. The software engineering curriculum prepares students for a career in reliable, economical software development.\n\nProgramming is only one phase (construction) of software engineering. There are many other aspects of the software engineering process, such as requirements definition, architectural design, and quality assurance, which need to be applied in order to develop reliable software on time and within budget constraints. The software engineering curriculum provides students a solid background in both the theory and practice of all phases in the software engineering process, beginning with their first course of study in the Department of Computer Science and Software Engineering, and continuing to the end of the senior year.\n\nSince software is a non-physical product developed and executed on computers, the software engineering curriculum has computer science as its primary engineering science. The computer science courses taken by software engineering majors include the study of algorithms, data structures, database concepts, computer architecture, programming languages and operating systems. Software engineering majors also complete important courses in other closely related fields, such as discrete mathematics, digital logic design, and engineering statistics.\n\nCoverage of software engineering topics begins in a three-term introduction to software development during the freshman and sophomore years. This study continues with coverage of core software engineering areas in the junior year, including software requirements, software architecture, software design, software project management, software construction, software maintenance, software evolution, software quality assurance, and formal methods in software specification and design. All of these courses include individual and team projects relevant to that particular area of software engineering. ", "lemma": "Software Engineering Software engineering be creation software use process similar other engineering disciplines. allow software be reliable develop time cost estimates. software engineering curriculum prepare student career reliable, economical software development. Programming be only phase (construction) software engineering. be many other aspect software engineering process, such requirement definition, architectural design, quality assurance, need be apply order develop reliable software time budget constraints. software engineering curriculum provide student solid background theory practice phase software engineering process, begin first course study Department Computer Science Software Engineering, continue end senior year. software be non-physical product develop execute computers, software engineering curriculum have computer science primary engineering science. computer science course take software engineering major include study algorithms, data structures, database concepts, computer program language operate systems. Software engineering major also complete important course other closely related fields, such discrete mathematics, digital logic design, engineering statistics. Coverage software engineering topic begin three-term introduction software development freshman sophomore years. study continue coverage core software engineering area junior year, include software requirements, software architecture, software design, software project management, software construction, software maintenance, software evolution, software quality assurance, formal method software specification design. course include individual team project relevant particular area software engineering."}

Throughout the senior year, a capstone team project develops and delivers software for a \u201creal-world\u201d client, which is put on display locally at a public exposition.\n\nThroughout society, software exists for a wide variety of application domain areas. Software Engineering Program Educational Objectives\n\nThe software engineering program prepares its graduates for many types of careers in the computing industry as well as for graduate study in software engineering and in closely related disciplines. Within a few years after completing the software engineering degree program, our graduates will:\n\nAdvance beyond their entry-level position to more responsible roles, or progress towards completion of advanced degree(s).\n\nContinue to keep pace with advancements in their disciplines, and develop professionally in response to changes in roles and responsibilities.\n\n", "lemma": "Software Engineering Program Educational Objectives software engineering program prepare graduate many type career computing industry as well graduate study software engineering closely related disciplines. few year complete software engineering degree graduate will: Advance entry-level position more responsible roles, progress towards completion advanced degree(s). {"source": "Software%20Engineering.txt", "text": "This is about Software Engineering txt. This is about Software Engineering txt. This is about Software Engineering txt. Contribute to the body of computing products, services, or knowledge.\n\nSoftware Engineering Student Outcomes\n\nBy the time students graduate with a Software Engineering degree from Rose-Hulman, they will be able to:\n\nan ability to identify, formulate, and solve complex engineering problems by applying principles of engineering, science, and mathematics\n\nan ability to apply engineering design to produce solutions that meet specified needs with consideration of public health, safety, and welfare, as well as global, cultural, social, environmental, and economic factors\n\nan ability to communicate effectively with a range of audiences\n\nan ability to recognize ethical and professional responsibilities in engineering situations and make informed judgments, which must consider the impact of engineering solutions in global, economic, environmental, and societal contexts\n\nan ability to function effectively on a team whose members together provide leadership, create a collaborative and inclusive environment, establish goals, plan tasks, and meet objectives\n\nan ability to develop and conduct appropriate experimentation, analyze and interpret data, and use engineering judgment to draw conclusions\n\nan ability to acquire and apply new knowledge as needed, using appropriate learning strategies.\n\nThe Computer Science and Software Engineering faculty strives to maintain an open atmosphere that encourages mutual respect and support as well as learning and sharing of knowledge.\n\n", "lemma": "Contribute body compute products, services, knowledge. Software Engineering Student Outcomes time student graduate Software Engineering degree Rose-Hulman, be able to: ability identify, formulate, solve complex engineering problem apply principle engineering, science, mathematics ability apply engineering design produce solution meet specified need consideration public health, safety, welfare, as well global, cultural, social, environmental, economic factor ability communicate effectively range audience ability recognize ethical professional responsibility engineering situation make inform judgments, consider impact engineering solution global, economic, environmental, societal context ability function effectively team member together provide leadership, create collaborative inclusive environment, establish goals, plan tasks, meet objective ability develop conduct appropriate experimentation, analyze interpret data, use engineering judgment draw conclusion ability acquire apply new knowledge needed, use appropriate learning strategies. Computer Science Software Engineering faculty strives maintain open atmosphere encourage mutual respect support as well learning sharing knowledge."}

The software engineering program is accredited by the Engineering Accreditation Commission of ABET, https://www.abet.org, under the commission\u2019s General Criteria and Program Criteria for Software and Similarly Named Engineering Programs.\n\nSOFTWARE ENGINEERING\n\nSummary of graduation requirements for the software engineering major\n\nTo complete the major in software engineering a student must complete the following:\n\nAll required courses listed by number in the schedule of courses above: CSSE120, CSSE132, CSSE220, CSSE230, CSSE232, CSSE280, CSSE304, CSSE332, CSSE333, CSSE371, CSSE372, CSSE373, CSSE374, CSSE375, CSSE376, CSSE477, CSSE497, CSSE498, CSSE499; ECE233, MA111, MA112, MA113, MA221, MA276, MA374, MA381; PH111, PH112, CHEM111; HUMH190, ENGLH290; RHIT100.\n\nEight credits of additional software engineering courses numbered between 300 and 492 and designated as software engineering electives. {"source": "Software%20Engineering.txt", "text": "This is about Software Engineering txt. This is about Software Engineering txt. This is about Software Engineering txt. The student\u2019s academic advisor must approve the course used to satisfy this requirement. Use of software engineering courses numbered 490 through 492 to fulfill this requirement must be approved by the department head. Credits used to satisfy any requirements for a minor or secondary major pursued by a student cannot also be used to satisfy SE elective requirements for the student\u2019s primary or secondary major in Software Engineering. Credits used by a student pursuing a secondary major in SE that are intended to satisfy the SE elective requirement can only be used to satisfy technical or free elective requirements within the student\u2019s primary major or not used towards any requirements within the primary major.\n\nFour additional credits of technical electives, consisting of any courses in bi- ology, chemistry, engineering (except software engineering and engineering management), geology, mathematics, biomathematics, or physics.\n\nFour additional credits of courses offered by the Department of Mathematics excluding MA351 MA356. The student\u2019s academic advisor must approve the coursesused to satisfy this requirement.\n\nFour credits of science electives, which can be any CHEM, GEOL, PH, or BIO courses not already required for the software engineering major.\n\nTwenty-eight credits of additional courses offered by the Department of Humanities and Social Sciences; the distribution of these courses must meet the requirements of that department.\n\n", "lemma": "student\u2019s academic advisor approve course use satisfy requirement. Use software engineering course number fulfill requirement be approve department head. A total of 192 credits.\n\nDATA SCIENCE MAJOR (SECOND MAJOR ONLY)\n\nData Science is open to all students as a second major; this means that the student will have some other discipline as their primary major.\u00a0 Students whose primary major is in Computer Science, Software Engineering or Mathematics will find the Data Science program the easiest since there is considerable overlap between those programs and the Data Science requirements\u00a0 Students from other disciplines are also encouraged to participate, but will have to take more courses.\u00a0 All students are encouraged to take the individual courses in the program, regardless of whether they wish to fulfill the second major requirements.\n\n", "lemma": "total credits. DATA SCIENCE MAJOR (SECOND MAJOR ONLY) Data Science be open student second major; mean student have other discipline primary major. Students primary major be Computer Science, Software Engineering Mathematics find Data Science program easy be considerable overlap program Data Science requirement Students other discipline be also encourage participate, have take more courses. student be encourage take individual course program, regardless wish fulfill second major requirements."}

This information can be found on [Schedule Lookup](https://prodwebxe-hv.rose-hulman.edu/regweb).\n  * Sophomores, Juniors, and Seniors are assigned to an advisor by the Department Head of their major.\n  * Transfer Students are assigned an advisor in their chosen major field at the time their credits are evaluated. See [Transfer Student](https://www.rose-hulman.edu/campus-life/student-services/registrar/rules-and-procedures/transfer-students.html).\n\n**Meeting with academic advisors**\n\nEach student will need to meet with their academic advisor at least once per\nterm. At the end of the meeting, academic advisors will distribute a unique\nregistration PIN, which is necessary for course\n[registration](https://www.rose-hulman.edu/campus-life/student-\nservices/registrar/rules-and-procedures/registration.html). Midterm grades for\neach advisee are made available to the academic advisor, which provides an\nopportunity to discuss any challenges the student may be experiencing.\n\n", "lemma": "information be find [Schedule Lookup](https://prodwebxe-hv.rose-hulman.edu/regweb). * Sophomores, Juniors, Seniors be assign advisor Department Head major. * Transfer Students be assign advisor chosen major field time credit be evaluated. {"source": "registrar", "text": "This is about registrar. This is about registrar. This is about registrar. The Faculty of\nRose-Hulman\n\n  * agree that regular attendance is necessary,\n  * endorse the faculty member's right to require attendance,\n  * support the assessment of grade penalties, including failure in the course for excessive absence, and\n  * expect each instructor to give careful thought to and to announce attendance policy.\n\n**  \nStipulation**  \nAt the beginning of each course, the instructor has the authority to determine\nand the responsibility to announce the extent to which any absence, excused or\nunexcused, or tardiness will affect the student's final grade. A student whose\ntotal absences in a course, excused or unexcused, exceed two per credit is\nliable to fail the course.\n\n**  \nExcused absences**  \nInstructors will normally permit make-up work to be done when a student has\nlegitimate conflicting obligations, including but not limited to illness,\nisolation, self-isolation, emergency, Institute-sponsored activities, or plant\ntrips. These conflicts do not excuse the student from course responsibilities.\nThe student is responsible for informing the instructor of any legitimate\nexcuses and making arrangements for make-up work, if permitted, as soon as\npossible. Whenever possible, the student must discuss unavoidable absences\nwith instructors in advance.\n\n**Group activities**  \nWhen more than one student will miss class because of a scheduled school\nactivity, school policy requires that a notice be circulated to the Faculty.\nThe faculty sponsor for the activity must submit a roster of students\ninvolved, stating the purpose, time(s), and date(s) of absence, to the Dean of\nStudents for approval. ", "lemma": "Faculty Rose-Hulman * agree regular attendance be necessary, * endorse faculty member's right require attendance, * support assessment grade penalties, include failure course excessive absence, * expect instructor give careful think announce attendance policy. ** Stipulation** beginning course, instructor have authority determine responsibility announce extent absence, excuse unexcused, tardiness affect student's final grade. A student total absence course, excuse unexcused, exceed credit be liable fail course. ** Excused absences** Instructors normally permit make-up work be do student have legitimate conflict obligations, include not limited illness, isolation, self-isolation, emergency, Institute-sponsored activities, plant conflict do not excuse student course responsibilities. student be responsible inform instructor legitimate excuse make arrangement make-up work, permitted, as soon possible. Whenever possible, student discuss unavoidable absence instructor advance. **Group activities** more student miss class scheduled school activity, school policy require notice be circulate Faculty. faculty sponsor activity submit roster student involved, state purpose, time(s), date(s) absence, Dean Students approval."}

The sponsor is responsible for having this notice\nduplicated and distributed to the Faculty not later than one week prior to the\nanticipated absence.\n\n**Plant trips**  \nAn Interview Plant Trip Form, available from the Placement Office, should be\nused by the student to notify instructors of an intended trip that will result\nin absence from class.\n\n**Exceptions or Questions:** Contact [Dean of\nStudents.", "lemma": "sponsor be responsible have notice duplicate distribute Faculty not later week prior anticipate absence. **Plant trips** Interview Plant Trip Form, available Placement Office, be use student notify instructor intended trip result absence class. **Exceptions Questions:** Contact [Dean Students."}

{"source": "registrar", "text": "This is about registrar. This is about registrar. This is about registrar. That is, if an [overload](overloads.html)\nis incurred, the student must meet the minimum GPA requirements and will be\ncharged accordingly.\n\nA student's registration may be changed from credit to audit or from audit to\ncredit, but may not do so later than the fifth day of classes in the term. To\naudit a course, the student must pick up an Audit Approval Form from the\nRegistrar's Office and check with the instructor who will determine if an\nAudit is permitted, what the criteria for 'successful completion' are, and\nwhat degree of participation will be expected or permitted. Then the student\nshould consult the adviser and return the signed form to the registrar's\noffice.\n\nA course successfully completed on an Audit basis does appear on the student's\npermanent record. It does not count toward graduation requirements, since no\ncredit is given. It is assigned an \"AU\" rather than a credit grade, and if the\ninstructor decides that the audit has been 'unsuccessful,' the instructor may\ndirect that the \"AU\" not be awarded and the Audit will be removed from the\nstudent's record.\n\n(A friendly note: many students who sign up to Audit a course later drop it or\npetition, unsuccessfully, to receive credit. ", "lemma": "is, [overload](overloads.html) be incurred, student meet minimum GPA requirement be charge student's registration be change credit audit audit credit, not do so later fifth day class term. audit course, student pick up Audit Approval Form Registrar's Office check instructor determine Audit be permitted, criterion 'successful completion' are, degree participation be expect permitted. {"source": "registrar", "text": "This is about registrar. This is about registrar. This is about registrar. * A sophomore is a student who has acquired at least 45 quarter-hour credits approved for the curriculum in which the student intends to receive a degree.\n  * A junior is a student who has acquired at least 95 quarter-hour credits approved for the curriculum in which the student intends to receive a degree.\n  * A senior is a student who has acquired at least 145 quarter-hour credits approved for the curriculum in which the student intends to receive a degree.\n\n**Special students**\n\nA Rose-Hulman student who plans to transfer out of Rose-Hulman or who wishes\nto take courses for some special purpose may be classified as a Special\nStudent. As such, the student is not a candidate for adegree and may enroll in\ncourses of choice (subject to prerequisite requirements). Credits earned while\nclassified as a Special Student may be applied toward the requirements for a\ndegree at a later date if the student petitions for, and is granted,\nreclassification as a regular student.\n\nA student desiring classification or re-classification as a Special Student\nshould submit to the Registrar a written petition to the Admissions and\nStanding Committee. If approved, student's records will show the\nclassification and notification will be given to the [student's\nadvisor](advisors.html) and the Dean of Students.\n\nIf a student who has been granted Special Student classification departs from\nthe established curricula and later petitions to become a regular degree\ncandidate, the student may not use the Special Student option as a means of\ncircumventing any of the usual degree requirements.  \n**Also see:  \n**\n\n  * [Enrollment of Local High School or Non-Degree Students](enrollment-non-degree.html)\n  * [Part-Time Student](part-time-student.html)\n  * [Transfer Student](transfer-students.html)\n\n**Exceptions & Questions:** Contact Admissions and Standing Committee.\n\n", "lemma": "* sophomore be student have acquire least quarter-hour credit approve curriculum student intend receive degree. * junior be student have acquire least quarter-hour credit approve curriculum student intend receive degree. * A senior be student have acquire least quarter-hour credit approve curriculum student intend receive degree. **Special students** Rose-Hulman student plan transfer Rose-Hulman wish take course special purpose be classify Special Student. such, student be not candidate adegree enroll course choice (subject prerequisite requirements). Credits earn while classify Special Student be apply requirement degree late date student petition for, be granted, reclassification regular student. student desire classification re-classification Special Student submit Registrar write petition Admissions Standing Committee. approved, student's record show classification notification be give [student's advisor](advisors.html) Dean Students. student have be grant Special Student classification departs establish curriculum late petition become regular degree candidate, student not use Special Student option mean circumvent usual degree requirements. **Also see: ** * [Enrollment Local High School Non-Degree Students](enrollment-non-degree.html) * [Part-Time Student](part-time-student.html) * [Transfer Student](transfer-students.html) **Exceptions Questions:** Contact Admissions Standing Committee."}

{"source": "registrar", "text": "This is about registrar. This is about registrar. This is about registrar. [White Background with Triangle Pattern](../../../../assets/images/overlay-\nimages/img-white-triangle.jpg)\n\n# Rules & Procedures - Concurrent Degrees\n\nLearn more about the Academic Rules & Procedures at Rose\u2011Hulman.\n\n  * [Home](../../../../index.html)\n  * [Campus Life](../../../index.html)\n  * [Student Services](../../index.html)\n  * [Office of the Registrar](../index.html)\n  * [Rules & Procedures](index.html)\n  * [Concurrent Degrees](concurrent-degrees.html)\n\n**In this section** Open Close\n\n### Overview\n\n  * [Student Records](../student-records/index.html)\n  * [Registration Services](../registration-services/index.html)\n  * [Forms](../forms.html)\n  * [Calendars & Schedules](../academic-calendars.html)\n  * [Rules & Procedures](index.html)\n  * [Course Catalog](../../../../academics/course-catalog/2019-2020/index.html)\n  * [Contact the Registrar](../contact-us.html)\n\n## Concurrent Pursuance of Bachelor\u00e2\u0080\u0099s & Master\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Degrees\n\nA student who, by reason of [Credit By Examination](credit-by-\nexamination.html), [Transfer Credit](transfer-credits.html), and/or [Overloads\n](overloads.html)has completed most of the requirements for the Bachelor's\ndegree and would be carrying less than a normal load while finishing those\nrequirements may elect to work toward the Master's degree while still\ncompleting Bachelor's degree requirements. Provision for Concurrent Pursuance\nof the Bachelor's and Master's degrees is designed for the student who plans\non completing the Bachelor's and Master's degree requirements in the same\nquarter. Students who are pursuing established concurrent Bachelor's and\nMaster's plans of study can double-count up to 12 credit hours of 500-level\ncourses taken at Rose-Hulman, in which they have achieved a grade of B or\nhigher, toward both their Bachelor's and Master's degrees.\n\nA student who wishes to take 12 hours or less for graduate credit should refer\nto the section entitled [Graduate Courses](graduate-studies.html).\n\n", "lemma": "[White Background Triangle Pattern](../../../../assets/images/overlay- images/img-white-triangle.jpg) Rules Procedures Concurrent Degrees Learn more Academic Rules Procedures Rose\u2011Hulman. * [Home](../../../../index.html) * [Campus Life](../../../index.html) * [Student Services](../../index.html) * [Office Registrar](../index.html) * [Rules Procedures](index.html) * [Concurrent Degrees](concurrent-degrees.html) **In section** Open Close ### Overview * [Student Records](../student-records/index.html) * [Registration Services](../registration-services/index.html) * [Forms](../forms.html) * [Calendars Schedules](../academic-calendars.html) * [Rules Procedures](index.html) * [Course Catalog](../../../../academics/course-catalog/2019-2020/index.html) * [Contact Registrar](../contact-us.html) ## Concurrent Pursuance Bachelor\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Master\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Degrees student who, reason [Credit Examination](credit-by- examination.html), [Transfer Credit](transfer-credits.html), and/or [Overloads ](overloads.html)has complete most requirement Bachelor's degree be carry less normal load finish requirement elect work Master's degree still complete Bachelor's degree requirements. Provision Concurrent Pursuance Bachelor's Master's degree be design student plan complete Bachelor's Master's degree requirement same quarter. Students be pursue establish concurrent Bachelor's Master's plan study double-count up credit hour 500-level course take Rose-Hulman, have achieve grade B higher, Bachelor's Master's degrees. A student wish take hour less graduate credit refer section entitle [Graduate Courses](graduate-studies.html)."}

{"source": "registrar", "text": "This is about registrar. This is about registrar. This is about registrar. 2. The student must complete a [Concurrent Pursuance Application Form](../_assets/forms/Concurrent_Pursuance_Application_Form.pdf) and formally apply to the graduate program. On this Form the student _[in conjunction with the undergraduate major advisor](https://www.rose-hulman.edu/campus-life/student-services/registrar/rules-and-procedures/advisers.html)_ , must propose a term-by-term plan of study, showing both the plan for completing the requirements for the Bachelor's degree and the proposed courses which are to be double-counted and those which are to apply only toward the Master's degree. The proposed plan of study must be endorsed by the Head(s) of the department(s) concerned--i.e., of both the Bachelor's and Master's programs--and approved by the Associate Dean of Lifelong Learning. Application materials should be obtained from and returned to the Associate Dean of Lifelong Learning.\n  ", "lemma": "student complete [Concurrent Pursuance Application Form](../_assets/forms/Concurrent_Pursuance_Application_Form.pdf) formally apply graduate program. Application material be obtain return Associate Dean Lifelong Learning."}
{"source": "registrar", "text": "This is about registrar. This is about registrar. This is about registrar. 3. In case of schedule conflicts, courses for the Bachelor's degree take precedence, and _[course substitution](https://www.rose-hulman.edu/campus-life/student-services/registrar/rules-and-procedures/course-substition.html)_ for required courses of the Bachelor's program will not be approved for the purpose of removing such conflicts.\n  4. The student can apply to the Master's program no earlier than the quarter in which the student attains Junior standing and no later than the start of the first quarter in which the student has 24 or fewer credit hours left to complete their Bachelor's degree requirements.\n\n  \n\n**Exceptions & Questions:** Contact [Graduate Studies\nCommittee](mailto:gradstudies_comm@rose-hulman.edu).\n\n", "lemma": "case schedule conflicts, course Bachelor's degree take precedence, _[course substitution](https://www.rose-hulman.edu/campus-life/student-services/registrar/rules-and-procedures/course-substition.html)_ required course Bachelor's program not be approve purpose remove such conflicts. student apply Master's program no earlier quarter student attain Junior standing later start first quarter student have few credit hour leave complete Bachelor's degree requirements. **Exceptions Questions:** Contact [Graduate Studies Committee](mailto:gradstudies_comm@rose-hulman.edu)."}

{"source": "registrar", "text": "This is about registrar. This is about registrar. This is about registrar. Because of the strict\nrequirements set for science and engineering curricula by accrediting\nagencies, such changes in curricular requirements cannot be made casually.\nSubstitutions may be approved in the case of a student who is changing\ncurriculum and has already taken a course in the old curriculum that is\nequivalentto one required in the new curriculum. Substitutions may also be\napproved if compliance with some course requirement of a published curriculum\nwould require unreasonable hardship for the student. Procedure The student\nmust complete a Course Substitution Approval Form also available in the\nregistrar's office. The completed form should be taken to the appropriate\ndepartment head(s) for approval or referral to the Curriculum Committee and\nreturned tothe registrar's office. If the course substitution request is\nreferred to the Curriculum Committee, the registrar will take it to the\nCurriculum Committee forapproval or denial. If there are two or more\ndissenting votes on the Committee, the petition must be brought before the\nentire Faculty for approval or denial.\n\n**Limitations**\n\n  1. Approval for Course Substitution must be obtained prior to registration for the student's final term at Rose-Hulman.\n  2. ", "lemma": "strict requirement set science engineering curriculum accredit agencies, such change curricular requirement cannot be make casually. Substitutions be approve case student be change curriculum have already take course old curriculum be equivalentto require new curriculum. Substitutions also be approve compliance course requirement publish curriculum require unreasonable hardship student. Procedure student complete Course Substitution Approval Form also available registrar's complete form be take appropriate department head(s) approval referral Curriculum Committee return tothe registrar's course substitution request be refer Curriculum Committee, registrar take Curriculum Committee forapproval denial. be more dissenting vote Committee, petition be bring entire Faculty approval denial. **Limitations** Approval Course Substitution be obtain prior registration student's final term Rose-Hulman."}

Catalog](../../../../academics/course-catalog/2019-2020/index.html)\n  * [Contact the Registrar](../contact-us.html)\n\n## Credit\n\nThe Institute guideline is that one credit hour represents approximately an\naverage of three hours of work by a typical student per week throughout a ten-\nweek academic quarter, or the equivalent amount of work over a different time.\n\"Work\" includes all activities necessary to achieve the objectives of the\nlearning experience (attending lectures, conducting laboratory experiments,\ncompleting assignments, studying for tests, etc.).\n\n[Contact the Registrar](../contact-us.html)\n\n[Launch Root Entering students most often obtain\nCredit by Examination through National Advanced Placement or International\nBaccalaureate examinations or by taking Placement Examinations offered by the\nvarious departments at Rose-Hulman. Students already in attendance may use\nCourse Examination and By-Passing.\n\n", "lemma": "[White Background Triangle Pattern](../../../../assets/images/overlay- images/img-white-triangle.jpg) Credit Examination Learn more credit examination Rose\u2011Hulman. * [Home](../../../../index.html) * [Campus Life](../../../index.html) * [Student Services](../../index.html) * [Office Registrar](../index.html) * [Rules Procedures](index.html) * [Credit Examination](credit-by-examination.html) **In section** Open Close ### Overview * [Student Records](../student-records/index.html) * [Registration Services](../registration-services/index.html) * [Forms](../forms.html) * [Calendars Schedules](../academic-calendars.html) * [Rules Procedures](index.html) * [Course Catalog](../../../../academics/course-catalog/2019-2020/index.html) * [Contact Registrar](../contact-us.html) ## Credit Examination Credit examination (graduation credit earn demonstrate knowledge course subject material enrol course) be obtain number ways, described Entering student most often obtain Credit Examination National Advanced Placement International Baccalaureate examination take Placement Examinations offer various department Rose-Hulman. Students already attendance use Course Examination By-Passing."}
{"source": "registrar", "text": "This is about registrar. This is about registrar. This is about registrar. A student who receives Credit by Examination for a course may use it to\nsatisfy graduation requirements and may enroll in more advanced courses. Note\nthat Credit by Examination does not carry a grade and hence does not influence\nthe student's GPA.\n\nCredit by Examination Options:\n\nAdvanced Placement (AP)  \nCambridge Exams  \nInternational Baccalaureate (IB)  \nCLEP Exams  \nRHIT Dept. Exams  \nCourse Examination  \nCourse By-Passing\n\n**National Advanced Placement Examinations (AP)**\n\nStudents who receive a score of 4 or 5 on a national AP examination will\nreceive credit by examination as described below. The decision whether or not\nto grant credit for courses other than those listed will be made by the\nappropriate Department Head.  \nAP Exam Conversions for RHIT Credit\n\n**AP Score  \nof 4 or 5**\n\n| **RHIT Credit Hours** | **RHIT Course Equivalent**  \n---|---|---  \nAFRICAN AMERICAN STUDIES | 4 | HUM H000  \nART HISTORY | 4 | ARTS H442  \nBIOLOGY | 4 | Score 4=BIO101; Score 5=BIO110  \nCALCULUS AB | 5 | MA111  \nCALCULUS BC | 10 | MA111 & MA 112  \nCHEMISTRY | ** | Score 4=8 cr hrs for CHEM 111, 113;  \nScore 5=12 cr hrs for CHEM 111, 113, 115  \nCHINESE LANG & CULTURE | ** | Score 4=8 cr hrs of foreign lang;  \nScore 5=12 cr hrs of foreign lang  \nCOMPUTER SCIENCE PRINCIPLES | 4 | 4 cr hrs 200-level CSSE elective  \nCOMPUTER SCIENCE A | 8 | Eligible for CSSE 220. Upon successful completion of\nCSSE 220, student is awarded 4 credits for CSSE 120 and 4 credits for CSSE\n220.  \n", "lemma": "student receive Credit Examination course use satisfy graduation requirement enroll more advanced courses. Note Credit Examination do not carry grade hence do not influence student's GPA. Credit Examination Options: Advanced Placement (AP) Cambridge Exams International Baccalaureate (IB) CLEP Exams RHIT Dept. Exams Course Examination Course By-Passing **National Advanced Placement Examinations (AP)** Students receive score national AP examination receive credit examination described decision not grant credit course other list be make appropriate Department Head. Upon\nsuccessful completion a quarter of more advanced language at Rose-Hulman with\na grade of C or better, the student will be granted 4 hours of Credit by\nExamination for each quarter of language by-passed. {"source": "registrar", "text": "This is about registrar. This is about registrar. This is about registrar. The student\nmust apply to the head of the appropriate department for such an exam and it\nis subject to the following limitations.\n\n  * The granting of Credit by Examination is normally limited to courses or areas available at Rose-Hulman or compatible with the curricula offered at Rose-Hulman.\n  * Credit by Examination cannot be used to make up a course failure (F or WF).\n  * Credit by Examination carries no grade and does not affect the student's GPA.\n  * Evaluation of special examinations will be made by the head of the department to determine whether a sufficient demonstration of knowledge of the particular course has been made to warrant Credit by Examination.\n\n**Course By-Passing**\n\nA student might, by reason of previous experience, be challenged little by a\nparticular course. In such a case, the student may, with the approval of the\nadvisor, the head of the department in which the course is offered, and the\ninstructor concerned, enroll in the succeeding course in the same subject and,\non completing that course with a grade of C or better, be granted Credit by\nExamination for the course(s) by-passed.\n\nExceptions & Questions: Contact Head of the appropriate department with\nquestions. ", "lemma": "student apply head appropriate department exam be subject following limitations. * granting Credit Examination be normally limit course area available Rose-Hulman compatible curriculum offer Rose-Hulman. * Credit Examination cannot be use make up course failure (F WF). * Credit Examination carry grade do not affect student's GPA. * Evaluation special examination be make head department determine sufficient demonstration knowledge particular course have be make warrant Credit Examination. **Course By-Passing** A student might, reason previous experience, be challenge little particular course. such case, student may, approval advisor, head department course be offered, instructor concerned, enroll succeed course same subject and, complete course grade C better, be grant Credit Examination course(s) by-passed. Exceptions Questions: Contact Head appropriate department questions."}

{"source": "registrar", "text": "This is about registrar. This is about registrar. This is about registrar. If the instructor agrees, a written\nproposal may be required from the student, specifying the reading and/or\nresearch to be undertaken, reports or tests to be used for grading purposes,\nnumber of meetings per week, number of credits to be awarded, etc.\n\n**Procedure**\n\nThe student should pick up and complete a Directed Research / Independent\nStudy form, available in the registrar's office. The completed form should be\nreturned to the registrar's office.\n\n**Limitations**\n\n  1. Directed Research / Independent Study courses may not be used to replace a failed course.\n  2. Directed Research / Independent Study courses may not be used for [Course Substitution.](course-substition.html)\n  3. All Directed Research / Independent Study courses must receive the approval of the appropriate Department Head.\n\n**Exceptions & Questions:** Consult Department Head.\n\n", "lemma": "instructor agrees, write proposal be require student, specify reading and/or research be undertaken, report test be use grade purposes, number meeting week, number credit be awarded, etc. student pick up complete Directed Research / Independent Study form, available registrar's complete form be return registrar's office. **Limitations** Directed Research / Independent Study course not be use replace failed course. Directed Research / Independent Study course not be use [Course Substitution.](course-substition.html) All Directed Research / Independent Study course receive approval appropriate Department Head. **Exceptions Questions:** Consult Department Head."}

{"source": "registrar", "text": "This is about registrar. This is about registrar. This is about registrar. All Institute administrative officials, faculty, and staff are authorized to\nenforce the rules and policies of the Institute, are expected to report any\nviolations thereof to the appropriate disciplinary agencies, and will be given\nfull legal support for Institute-related disciplinary actions they may take,\non or off campus. All Institute personnel are urged to be both firm and fair\nin taking disciplinary action and to do so in consultation with other\nInstitute personnel to avoid illegal actions.  \n**Authority**  \n  \nThe Board of Trustees has granted authority to the President of the Institute,\nin an instance of major disturbance or civil disobedience involving physical\nviolence or adamant insubordination, to exercise civil authority to maintain\ndecorum and discipline on the campus, to immediately dismiss any student or\nemployee who refuses to leave the scene of the disturbance.  \n  \nThe Board has granted authority to the Faculty responsibility for all matters\ninvolving student discipline including the ability to admit and dismiss\n(suspend) students. The Faculty has delegated to the Dean of Students and to\nthe Institute Rules and Discipline Committee the authority to dismiss a\nstudent, i.e., to impose temporary or permanent suspension.  \n  \n**Procedures and appeals in cases of non-academic misconduct**\n\n  1. Non-Academic Misconduct includes action such as theft, damage, or unauthorized use of Institute property; the disruption of Institute activities on or off campus; disorderly conduct on Institute property or in off-campus fraternity or sorority houses, or violations of Institute regulations as set forth in the Student Handbook.\n  2. {"source": "registrar", "text": "This is about registrar. This is about registrar. This is about registrar. 4. Whenever a student is charged with Non-Academic Misconduct, a disciplinary conference will be scheduled with the Dean of Students. If the facts of the case and the penalties to be imposed can be agreed upon, the Dean of Students and the student will sign a Statement of Agreement.  This Statement of Agreement, when signed, will constitute a waiver of the right to a hearing or any appeal and an acceptance of the findings and penalties imposed.\n  5. If an agreement cannot be reached regarding both the facts of the case and the penalty to be imposed (i.e., a Statement of Agreement has not been signed) and the Dean of Students has determined that suspension from Rose-Hulman may be warranted, then the Dean of Students has the authority to suspend the student or refer the case to the Rules and Discipline Committee.  If the Dean of Students determines that suspension is not an appropriate penalty, and a Statement of Agreement has not been signed, the student must select one of the following three committees to hear the case. The chair of the chosen committee must be contacted within five business days. If none of the chairs are contacted within five business days, then the Dean of Students will issue a ruling which is final. \n    * A hearing by the Student Judicial Council. The Student Judicial Council is a committee of students appointed by the Student Government Association to handle cases of non-academic misconduct. The student may have counsel with him or her (a current student, faculty, or staff member). A faculty member, the Dean of Students or other Institute official, or a Board of Inquiry may bring a case against a student.\n\nThe party requesting a hearing shall submit a complete written statement to\nthe Chairperson of the Committee, who will distribute copies to all persons\ninvolved and to the Dean of Students. The Chairperson shall invite the other\nparties involved to submit written rebuttal statements. The Chairperson shall\nschedule a hearing date and notify all parties, calling the procedures herein\ndescribed to their attention so that they will be aware of their rights and of\nthe conduct of the hearing. {"source": "registrar", "text": "This is about registrar. This is about registrar. This is about registrar. All this shall be accomplished as expeditiously as\npossible, preferably within a few days.  \nAt the hearing, the student may be accompanied by a faculty member or other\nperson affiliated with the Institute to serve as counsel. The Chairperson\nshall contact the student prior to the hearing to ascertain whether counsel is\nrequired and, if necessary, shall assist in the selection.  \nThe accused has the right to hear all testimony, to examine all evidence, to\nquestion all witnesses, to present evidence, and to ask that witnesses be\ncalled on the accused's behalf. The student also has the right to remain\nsilent and a decision to do so will not be taken as an admission of guilt.  \nWitnesses may be requested to appear before the Committee by the Chairperson\nif desired by the accused, by the person bringing charges, or by the Committee\nitself.  \nAny member of the Committee directly involved in the case under consideration\nor who, for any reason, would be biased in the case, will be excused from the\nhearing by the Chairperson. The accused and the accused's counsel may petition\nthe Chairperson to excuse a Committee member whom they believe holds a serious\nbias in the case.  \nGuilt or innocence in a case shall be determined solely on the merits of that\ncase. The Committee shall not review the previous disciplinary record of the\naccused before the hearing, or permit such information to be introduced in the\nhearing, or allow such knowledge as they may have to bias their judgment.  \nAny finding requires concurrence by a majority of Committee members taking\npart in the hearing.  \n", "lemma": "be accomplish as expeditiously possible, preferably few days. hearing, student be accompany faculty member other person affiliate Institute serve counsel. Witnesses be request appear Committee Chairperson desire accused, person bring charges, Committee itself. Any member Committee directly involve case consideration who, reason, be bias case, be excuse hearing Chairperson. accuse accused's counsel petition Chairperson excuse Committee member believe hold serious bias case. Guilt innocence case be determine solely merit case. Committee not review previous disciplinary record accuse hearing, permit such information be introduce hearing, allow such knowledge have bias judgment. find require concurrence majority Committee member take part hearing."}
{"source": "registrar", "text": "This is about registrar. This is about registrar. This is about registrar. A recording of the hearing will be made.  \nAfter the close of the hearing, the Committee will privately consider the\ncase, call additional meetings if necessary, reach a decision, notify all\nparties of the decision, and prepare a brief written statement. Copies of this\nstatement will be sent to all parties and to the Dean of Students to be made a\npart of the student's personal (not academic) record.  \nThe intent of the foregoing procedures is to make clear to all parties what\nwill occur during the hearing and to safeguard the rights of the accused. It\nis also their intent to make the hearings as relaxed as possible and to permit\nfree interchange of information between the accused and the Committee in an\neffort to ascertain the relevant facts of the case.  \n  \n", "lemma": "recording hearing be made. close hearing, Committee privately consider case, call additional meeting necessary, reach decision, party decision, prepare brief write statement. {"source": "registrar", "text": "This is about registrar. This is about registrar. This is about registrar. **Committee actions**\n\n  1. In the case of a student appealing the disciplinary action of an instructor, the Committee may uphold the action of the instructor, may decide that the student is innocent, or may decide that the student has been too severely penalized. Accordingly, it may recommend that the instructor reconsider actions (such as lowering a grade) that have been taken. However, because of the limitations of academic freedom, the Committee is not empowered to change any grade. If the instructor chooses not to follow the Committee's recommendation the Committee will prepare a written statement of its findings for inclusion in the student's personal records. It is hereby specifically noted that, in cases of student appeal, the Committee may not recommend penalties in addition to those which the instructor has already imposed.\n  ", "lemma": "**Committee actions** case student appeal disciplinary action instructor, Committee uphold action instructor, decide student be innocent, decide student have be too severely penalized. Accordingly, recommend instructor reconsider action (such lower grade) have be taken. However, limitation academic freedom, Committee be not empower change grade. instructor choose not follow Committee's recommendation Committee prepare write statement finding inclusion student's personal records. be hereby specifically noted that, case student Committee not recommend penalty addition instructor have already imposed."}
{"source": "registrar", "text": "This is about registrar. This is about registrar. This is about registrar. 2. In the case of a student appealing a suspension by the Dean of Students, the Committee may affirm the suspension, may mitigate the suspension (changing permanent suspension to temporary suspension or reducing the terms of suspension), or may remove the suspension and recommend that the Dean substitute other penalties or that no penalties be assessed. The Committee may not levy additional penalties. The Committee is not empowered to review other disciplinary actions of the Dean, such as removing a student from the Residence Halls, which may be appealed to the President of the Institute.\n  3. ", "lemma": "case student appeal suspension Dean Students, Committee affirm suspension, mitigate suspension (changing permanent suspension temporary suspension reduce term suspension), remove suspension recommend Dean substitute other penalty penalty be Committee not levy additional penalties. Committee be not empower review other disciplinary action Dean, such remove student Residence Halls, be appeal President Institute."}
{"source": "registrar", "text": "This is about registrar. This is about registrar. This is about registrar. In the case of a hearing initiated against a student, if the Committee finds the student innocent it may recommend, but cannot require, that any penalties previously assessed be removed. Its report shall include its determination of innocence and shall direct that all written reports of the case be expunged from the student's personal record unless the student requests that they be retained. For example, they may be retained in an instance where a course grade has been lowered by the instructor but the Committee subsequently exonerated the student.\n  ", "lemma": "case hearing initiate student, Committee find student innocent recommend, cannot require, penalty previously assess be removed. report include determination innocence direct write report case be expunge student's personal record student request be retained. example, be retain instance course grade have be lower instructor Committee subsequently exonerate student."}
{"source": "registrar", "text": "This is about registrar. This is about registrar. This is about registrar. 4. In the case of a hearing initiated against a student, if the Committee renders a finding of guilty, the Dean of Students will then review the student's previous disciplinary record, if any, to aid the Committee in its decision as to the penalty. Penalty options include, but are not limited to, a reprimand, a recommendation to the instructor that the student's grade be lowered or that the student be failed in the course, suspension of the student from extra-curricular activities, a referral of the case to civil authorities, or suspension of the student from the Institute. The Committee will not seek to devise 'novel' penalties or forms of restitution unless they seem clearly appropriate and do not constitute 'cruel and unusual punishment'.\n  ", "lemma": "case hearing initiate student, Committee render finding guilty, Dean Students then review student's previous disciplinary record, any, aid Committee decision penalty. Penalty option include, be not limited to, reprimand, recommendation instructor student's grade be lower student be fail course, suspension student extra-curricular activities, referral case civil authorities, suspension student Institute. Committee not seek devise 'novel' penalty form restitution seem clearly appropriate do not constitute 'cruel unusual punishment'."}
{"source": "registrar", "text": "This is about registrar. This is about registrar. This is about registrar. Any decision to suspend or to uphold a suspension or summary dismissal imposed by the Dean of Students, the President, or another officer of the Institute, may be appealed to the Faculty. (See below.) In all other cases, the decision of the Committee is final; that is, no further appeal is permitted by the student and no penalties beyond those recommended by the Committee should be assessed by the instructor.\n\n  \n**Suspension by the Institute rules and discipline committee**\n\n  1. Should the Committee decide to suspend the student from the Institute, it will notify the Dean of Students, the Registrar, and the Chairperson of the Admissions and Standing Committee of the suspension. A student choosing to appeal the decision to the Faculty, may remain enrolled and in attendance at the Institute until the appeal has been heard, unless the Committee shall decide on immediate dismissal for reasons relating to the well-being of the student, of other persons, or of the Institute.\n  2. ", "lemma": "decision suspend uphold suspension summary dismissal impose Dean Students, President, officer Institute, be appeal Faculty. (See below.) other cases, decision Committee be final; is, further appeal be permit student penalty recommend Committee be assess instructor. **Suspension Institute rule discipline committee** Committee decide suspend student Institute, notify Dean Students, Registrar, Chairperson Admissions Standing Committee suspension. A student choose appeal decision Faculty, remain enrolled attendance Institute appeal have be heard, Committee decide immediate dismissal reason relate well-being student, other persons, Institute."}

{"source": "registrar", "text": "This is about registrar. This is about registrar. This is about registrar. The following\nprocedures are used to make schedule changes thereafter:\n\n**Changes before the term begins:** If Department Heads and/or the Registrar's\nOffice discovers a problem in a student's registration (e.g., section\noverfilled, course cancellation), it may be necessary to move a student to\nanother section of a class. Students should check their schedules regularly\nfor changes through the first day of the term. If a student finds it necessary\nto make a schedule change, they may use their pin prior to the first day of\nthe term. Students are always encouraged to speak with their advisor regarding\nschedule changes.\n\n**Changes in the first week:** The first five days of class in a term are\ndesignated as Drop/Add week during which time a student may request schedule\nchanges that were not completed prior to the start of term. Students initiate\nthe request using the electronic Drop/Add Form from MyRose-Hulman (under\nRegistrar Forms). Once submitted by the student, forms are routed\nelectronically to the necessary approvers (noted below). Adding a course is\nonly permitted through the fifth day of classes in the term.\n\n  * Change in course or section (add and drop): Approval required by Add Instructor; Notification to Drop Instructor and Advisor.\n  * Adding a course: Approval required by Add Instructor; Notification to Advisor.\n  * Dropping a course: Notification to Drop Instructor and Advisor.\n\n  \n\n**Changes after the first week:**\n\n  1. Up until the end of the eighth week of a term, a student may withdraw from a course by submitting the Course Withdrawal Request form found on My Rose-Hulman (under Registrar Forms). The request will be electronically submitted for approval from the course instructor and the student's advisor. {"source": "registrar", "text": "This is about registrar. This is about registrar. This is about registrar. Javascript must be enabled for the correct page display\n\nSkip to content\n\n![White Background with Triangle Pattern](../../../../assets/images/overlay-\nimages/img-white-triangle.jpg)\n\n# Rules & Procedures - Enrollment of Non-Degree Students\n\nLearn more about the Academic Rules & Procedures at Rose\u2011Hulman.\n\n  * [Home](../../../../index.html)\n  * [Campus Life](../../../index.html)\n  * [Student Services](../../index.html)\n  * [Office of the Registrar](../index.html)\n  * [Rules & Procedures](index.html)\n  * [Enrollment of Non-Degree Students](enrollment-non-degree.html)\n\n**In this section** Open Close\n\n### Overview\n\n  * [Student Records](../student-records/index.html)\n  * [Registration Services](../registration-services/index.html)\n  * [Forms](../forms.html)\n  * [Calendars & Schedules](../academic-calendars.html)\n  * [Rules & Procedures](index.html)\n  * [Course Catalog](../../../../academics/course-catalog/2019-2020/index.html)\n  * [Contact the Registrar](../contact-us.html)\n\n## Enrollment of Local High School or Non-Degree Students\n\nAn academically talented student who lives at home, attends a local high\nschool and has written permission from parents or legal guardian and the high\nschool, or other members of the community have two options regarding the\npossibility of attending classes at Rose-Hulman Institute of Technology.\nNeither of these options includes or implies admission to Rose-Hulman\nInstitute of Technology as a regular degree-seeking student.\n\nUnder the first option, the student may take a course for graded credit by\nfilling out a \"Non-Degree Student\" application to be submitted to the Rose-\nHulman Committee on Admissions and Standing for approval. After the\napplication is approved, the student pays the prevailing per-credit-hour\ntuition, and a permanent Rose-Hulman Institute of Technology academic record\nis generated for the student. This procedure is followed each quarter the\nstudent wishes to take a class (or classes) at Rose-Hulman Institute of\nTechnology. In the case of a local high school student, the Rose-Hulman\nRegistrar sends a copy of the completed and approved \"Non-Degree Student\"\napplication to the high school.\n\nThe Second option is less formal in that the student contacts the head of the\ndepartment teaching the course in which enrollment is desired and asks the\ndepartment head for permission to attend class. If the head of the department\napproves the request, the student fills out a \"Guest Student\" application and\nsubmits it to the Registrar, who forwards a copy to the high school if\napplicable. Under this option, the student pays no tuition, and no official\nrecords are generated. {"source": "registrar", "text": "This is about registrar. This is about registrar. This is about registrar. No final examinations may be scheduled by anyone at any time prior to the\nregularly scheduled starting time for final examinations as published.\nExceptions to this rule may be made only by vote of the Faculty. This rule\ndoes not preclude examinations being given during regularly scheduled class\ntime. The Faculty has agreed to minimize the use of tests, quizzes, and\nexaminations during the last week of regularly scheduled classes in each term,\nespecially in classes which have final examinations.\n\n**Scheduling conflicts**\n\nA schedule of final examinations is made available each term. A student who is\nscheduled to take two final examinations at the same time or is scheduled for\nmore than two final examinations on the same day should immediately consult\nwith the instructors involved about re-scheduling.\n\n**Graduating seniors**\n\nIn order to facilitate the necessary administrative work for seniors\ngraduating at the end of the spring term, no examinations will be scheduled\nfor them after the last day of classes. The instructor of a spring term class\nwhich contains graduating seniors should arrange the testing of the seniors\ncommensurate with the deadline for submission of grades for graduating\nseniors.\n\n**Exceptions & Questions:** Consult the [Dean of the\nFaculty](mailto:deanoffaculty@rose-hulman.edu).\n\n", "lemma": "final examination be schedule anyone time prior regularly schedule starting time final examination published. Exceptions rule be make only vote Faculty. rule do not preclude examination be give regularly schedule class time. Faculty have agree minimize use tests, quizzes, examination last week regularly schedule class term, especially class have final examinations. **Scheduling conflicts** schedule final examination be make available term. A student be schedule take final examination same time be schedule more final examination same day immediately consult instructor involve re-scheduling. **Graduating seniors** order facilitate necessary administrative work senior graduate end spring term, examination be schedule last day classes. instructor spring term class contain graduate senior arrange testing senior commensurate deadline submission grade graduate seniors. **Exceptions Questions:** Consult [Dean Faculty](mailto:deanoffaculty@rose-hulman.edu)."}

This is computed by dividing the number\nof grade points earned in that term by the number of academic credits\nattempted in that term. ", "lemma": "[White Background Triangle Pattern](../../../../assets/images/overlay- images/img-white-triangle.jpg) Rules Procedures GPA Learn more Academic Rules Procedures Rose\u2011Hulman. * [Home](../../../../index.html) * [Campus Life](../../../index.html) * [Student Services](../../index.html) * [Office Registrar](../index.html) * [Rules Procedures](index.html) * [GPA](gpa.html) **In section** Open Close ### Overview * [Student Records](../student-records/index.html) * [Registration Services](../registration-services/index.html) * [Forms](../forms.html) * [Calendars Schedules](../academic-calendars.html) * [Rules Procedures](index.html) * [Course Catalog](../../../../academics/course-catalog/2019-2020/index.html) * [Contact Registrar](../contact-us.html) ## Grade-Point Average end term, student's academic achievement be measure numerical index call Term GPA. be compute divide number grade point earn term number academic credit attempt term."}
{"source": "registrar", "text": "This is about registrar. This is about registrar. This is about registrar. For more information, see [Grades](grades.html).\n\n  * Cumulative Grade Point Average: The student's grade report each term also shows the Cumulative GPA, which is obtained by dividing the total accumulated grade points by the total number of academic credits attempted.\n  * Grade Point Average in Major: After a student has earned 95 quarter hours of credit, the GPA in the student's major appears on the grade report. Each academic department determines which courses are used to calculate GPA in major.\n\n**GPA requirement**\n\nThe student must have a cumulative GPA of at least 2.000 and a GPA in major of\nat least 2.000. If not, the student may be permitted to enroll for additional\ncourses to remove this deficiency. ", "lemma": "more information, see [Grades](grades.html). * Cumulative Grade Point Average: student's grade report term also show Cumulative GPA, be obtain divide total accumulate grade point total number academic credit attempted. * Grade Point Average Major: student have earn quarter hour credit, GPA student's major appear grade report. academic department determines course be use calculate GPA major. **GPA requirement** student have cumulative GPA least GPA major least not, student be permit enroll additional course remove deficiency."}

In turn,\ninstructors will make every reasonable effort to ensure that grades are a fair\nand accurate assessment of each student's performance. ", "lemma": "Javascript be enable correct page display Skip content ![White Background Triangle Pattern](../../../../assets/images/overlay- images/img-white-triangle.jpg) Grade Appeals * [Home](../../../../index.html) * [Campus Life](../../../index.html) * [Student Services](../../index.html) * [Office Registrar](../index.html) * [Rules Procedures](index.html) * [Grade Appeals](grade-appeals.html) ## Course Grade Appeal Policy Institute recognize instructor retain sole responsibility evaluation student course work and, bar extraordinary circumstances, retain sole right assign grade student courses. turn, instructor make reasonable effort ensure grade be fair accurate assessment student's performance."}

{"source": "registrar", "text": "This is about registrar. This is about registrar. This is about registrar. In most\ncases, an in-person meeting will resolve the issue and no further action will\nbe required.\n\nHowever, if the student's concerns remain unresolved, the student may approach\nthe instructor's immediate administrative supervisor with a written memo\nwithin two weeks of the receipt of the grade.\n\n  * If the instructor's supervisor, either the department head (if the instructor is a faculty member) or the Dean of Faculty (if the instructor is a department head), believes the complaint has merit, the supervisor will discuss it with the instructor in an attempt to resolve the issue. This discussion will be summarized in a memo signed by both parties and shared with the student.\n\n  * In the rare case that the matter still remains unresolved, the student may appeal in a second written memo to the Dean of Faculty (if the instructor is a faculty member) or to the Vice President for Academic Affairs (if the instructor is a department head) within one week of the receipt of the first memo.\n\n  * The Dean of Faculty (if the instructor is a faculty member) or the VPAA (if the instructor is a department head) can reject the student's claim or request a review by faculty members in the department or in closely aligned fields. {"source": "registrar", "text": "This is about registrar. This is about registrar. This is about registrar. The appropriate administrator will select three faculty members to serve on the grade review panel.\n\n  * If a simple majority of the reviewers, through their inquiries, determine that compelling reasons exist for a grade change, they will notify the course instructor, department head, and Dean of Faculty or VPAA in a memo.\n\n  * If the instructor declines to change the grade, the instructor will provide an explanation in writing to the reviewers, department head, and Dean of Faculty or VPAA.\n\n  * The reviewers will consider the explanation and if they believe it would be unjust for the grade to stand, they will notify the faculty member, supervisor, Dean of Faculty or VPAA, and Registrar of their grade change decision. The Registrar will change the grade.\n\n  * The Dean of Faculty will inform faculty and staff of successful grade appeals at institute meetings.\n\nOnly the faculty review panel will have the ability to change a grade over the\nobjection of the instructor who assigned the original grade. Under no\ncircumstances will administrative officers--whether a department head, the\nDean of Faculty, or the VPAA--on their own authority substitute their judgment\nfor that of the faculty concerning the assignment of a grade. Every element of\nthe grade appeals process will be overseen and ultimately authorized by\nfaculty.\n\n", "lemma": "appropriate administrator select faculty member serve grade review panel. * simple majority reviewers, inquiries, determine compel reason exist grade change, notify course instructor, department head, Dean Faculty VPAA memo. * instructor decline change grade, instructor provide explanation write reviewers, department head, Dean Faculty VPAA. * reviewer consider explanation believe be unjust grade stand, notify faculty member, supervisor, Dean Faculty VPAA, Registrar grade change decision. Registrar change grade. * Dean Faculty inform faculty staff successful grade appeal institute meetings. Only faculty review panel have ability change grade objection instructor assign original grade. circumstance administrative officers--whether department head, Dean Faculty, VPAA--on own authority substitute judgment faculty concern assignment grade. Every element grade appeal process be overseen ultimately authorize faculty."}

{"source": "registrar", "text": "This is about registrar. This is about registrar. This is about registrar. **Limitations**\n\n  1. All grades will be recorded; that is, the prior penalty grade will not be removed from the student's permanent record.\n  2. If the penalty grade was an F, the student must repeat the course prior to taking any other course for which the repeated course is a prerequisite.\n  3. Grade replacement cannot be used for a course in which a penalty grade was assigned for disciplinary reasons.\n\n  \n**Procedure**  \n  \nThe student simply registers as usual for any courses for which Grade\nReplacement applies. If a student, after registering, finds that a course must\nbe repeated (e.g., after final grades have been reported), a [Drop/Add](drop-\nand-add.html) Form must be obtained during the first week of classes in the\nnext term.  \n  \nAlso see [Repeating a Course](repeating-a-course.html).  \n  \n ", "lemma": "All grade be recorded; is, prior penalty grade not be remove student's permanent record. penalty grade be F, student repeat course prior take other course repeated course be prerequisite. {"source": "registrar", "text": "This is about registrar. This is about registrar. This is about registrar. Usually, this is on Monday of the 6th week. The Mid-Term Grade\nreflects the performance on the graded work during the first five weeks of the\nterm but does not necessarily represent half of the final grade in the course.  \n  \nFinal Grades for each student, along with term and cumulative GPA, are made\navailable to the student by the Registrar, usually within a week after the end\nof finals. Students whose grades place them on [Probation](probation-and-\ndismissal.html) will also receive a letter from the Registrar at this time.  \n  \nThe Final Grade Reports are filed with the Registrar's Office and made\navailable to the student's advisor and the Dean of Students. At the beginning\nof the next term, the student is expected to confer promptly with the advisor\nabout scholastic progress.  \n  \n**Grade change report**  \n  \nIf a student completes the work to remove an Incomplete grade from the\nacademic record, or if a grade assigned in a course is to be changed for other\nreasons (e.g., an error made by the instructor in calculating the grade), a\nGrade Change Report listing the reason for the grade change must be filled out\nby the instructor and sent to the Registrar through the Dean of the Faculty. A\ncopy of the Grade Change Report or a revised Grade Report may be sent to the\nstudent or the change may simply be reflected in the next term's cumulative\n[GPA](gpa.html). If the grade change is not reflected in the next term's\ncumulative GPA, the student should verify with the Registrar's Office that the\nchange has been recorded on the permanent record.  \n  \nAlso see [Graduation Requirements](graduation-requirements.html).  \n  \n", "lemma": "be Monday week. Mid-Term Grade reflect performance graded work first week term do not necessarily represent half final grade course. Final Grades student, term cumulative GPA, be make available student Registrar, usually week end finals. Students grade place [Probation](probation-and- dismissal.html) also receive letter Registrar time. Final Grade Reports be file Registrar's Office make available student's advisor Dean Students. beginning next term, student be expect confer promptly advisor scholastic progress. **Grade change report** student complete work remove Incomplete grade academic record, grade assign course be be change other reason (e.g., error make instructor calculate grade), Grade Change Report list reason grade change be fill out instructor send Registrar Dean Faculty. A copy Grade Change Report revise Grade Report be send student change simply be reflect next term's cumulative [GPA](gpa.html). grade change be not reflect next term's cumulative GPA, student verify Registrar's Office change have be record permanent record. Also see [Graduation Requirements](graduation-requirements.html)."}

{"source": "registrar", "text": "This is about registrar. This is about registrar. This is about registrar. * \"A\" is an honor grade. It is awarded as a mark of outstanding performance and for achievement clearly of a higher order than average. It indicates that the student has demonstrated not only the ability to work successfully, but also the ability to do some creative thinking or problem solving in the field. {"source": "registrar", "text": "This is about registrar. This is about registrar. This is about registrar. It will not be given for routine performance of the assigned work in the course.\n  * \"B\" and \"B+\" indicate very good performance, definitely above a satisfactory level, but not as good in analytical thinking and originality as that required for the grade of \"A.\" Thorough competence to do excellent work in the field is required for the grades of \"B\" and \"B+\" which will not be given for mere compliance with the minimum essential standards of the course.\n  * \"C\" and \"C+\" are the grades given for satisfactory performance. They indicate compliance with the standards set for successful completion of the course and minimum performance acceptable for graduation from the Institute.\n  * \"D\" and \"D+\" are penalty grades. They are recorded to show that the student's performance has been below a satisfactory level, deficient in quality and/or content, and not of a standard high enough in this field to meet graduation requirements. ", "lemma": "not be give routine performance assigned work course. * \"B\" \"B+\" indicate very good performance, definitely satisfactory level, not as good analytical thinking originality require grade \"A.\" Thorough competence do excellent work field be require grade \"B\" \"B+\" not be give mere compliance minimum essential standard course. * \"C\" \"C+\" be grade give satisfactory performance. indicate compliance standard set successful completion course minimum performance acceptable graduation Institute. * \"D\" \"D+\" be penalty grades. be record show student's performance have be satisfactory level, deficient quality and/or content, not standard high enough field meet graduation requirements."}

{"source": "registrar", "text": "This is about registrar. This is about registrar. This is about registrar. For more information see [Grade Replacement](grade-replacement.html).\n  * \"W\" indicates \"Withdrawal,\" and is ignored in computing GPA. It is assigned automatically when the student withdraws properly between the beginning of the second week through the end of the eighth week of a term.  If the penalty levied by an instructor in a case of academic misconduct is failure in the course, the student forfeits the right to withdraw from the course with a grade of \"W\". For more information see [Drop/Add](drop-and-add.html).\n  ", "lemma": "more information see [Grade Replacement](grade-replacement.html). * \"W\" indicate \"Withdrawal,\" be ignore compute GPA. be assign automatically student withdraw properly beginning second week end eighth week term. penalty levy instructor case academic misconduct be failure course, student forfeit right withdraw course grade \"W\". more information see [Drop/Add](drop-and-add.html)."}

{"source": "registrar", "text": "This is about registrar. This is about registrar. This is about registrar. (Note: Whenever an \"I\" is given to a student, the instructor should give the Registrar a memorandum indicating the requirements for obtaining a passing grade in the course and an estimate of the grade on the work completed so far.)\n  * \"N\" indicates \"No Report\" and is used when insufficient information is available to allow a letter grade to be assigned or for a course in which credit is to be carried over in a continuation of the same course, such as graduate thesis credit or a senior seminar.\n  * \"AU\" indicates successful \"Audit\" in a course the student has registered for without receiving credit. If the audit has been 'unsuccessful,' (e.g., if the student did not actually attend class), the instructor may direct that the \"AU\" not be awarded and the Audit will be removed from the student's record.\n\n###\n\n**AY1920 Spring Grades of CR, DCR, NCR**\n\nAny class completed for undergraduate credit during the AY1920 Spring term, at\nthe discretion of the student, may be taken under the credit/no-credit grading\noption with the following designations:\n\n  * CR: Satisfactory. Replaces grades of C or better in the regular grading system. {"source": "registrar", "text": "This is about registrar. This is about registrar. This is about registrar. No credit is granted for this course.\n\nCourses taken under the credit/no-credit grading option will not be included\nin the calculation of the student's GPA. There is no limit to the number of\ncourses which can be taken under the credit/no-credit grading option.\n\nIf a student selects the credit/no-credit option for a course being taken for\ngrade replacement, and a grade of CR or DCR is earned, the prior penalty grade\nwill not be used in the computation of the student's GPA, but the prior\npenalty grade will not be removed from the student's permanent record. A grade\nof CR will meet prerequisite requirements. Students can only earn credit for\none instance of a repeated course. Grades of CR and DCR will allow the student\nto earn credit for a course previously failed. Stated limitations associated\nwith Grade Replacement still apply. It is strongly recommended that students\ndiscuss repeated courses with their advisors if they are considering the\ncredit/no-credit grading option for a repeated course.\n\nIf the penalty levied by an instructor in a case of academic misconduct is\nfailure in the course, the student forfeits the right to take the course under\nthe credit/no-credit grading option.\n\nStudents currently on probation or double-probation will retain that status\nuntil a later term if they do not take at least 12 hours of graded coursework\nduring the AY1920 Spring term.\n\n**For more information** also see [Grade Point Average](gpa.html) (GPA) and\n[Grade Reports](grade-reports.html).\n\n", "lemma": "credit be grant course. A grade CR meet prerequisite requirements. Students only earn credit instance repeat course. Grades CR DCR allow student earn credit course previously failed. Stated limitation associate Grade Replacement still apply. be strongly recommend student discuss repeat course advisor be consider credit/no-credit grading option repeat course. penalty levy instructor case academic misconduct be failure course, student forfeit right take course credit/no-credit grade option. Students currently probation double-probation retain status late term do not take least hour graded coursework AY1920 Spring term. **For more information** also see [Grade Point Average](gpa.html) (GPA) [Grade Reports](grade-reports.html)."}

However, it must be understood that this\ndoes not constitute acceptance to any graduate school, nor does it guarantee\nthat the course will be accepted for graduate credit toward any graduate\ndegree plan.
